questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a dry cough and chest discomfort for the past 3 days. During this period, the patient has had headaches, muscle aches, joint pain, fever, and chills. Ten days ago, she was hiking with her family in Mississippi. The patient has asthma that is treated with an albuterol inhaler. Her mother has a lung disease treated with methotrexate. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Physical examination shows slight wheezes throughout both lung fields. Urinalysis is positive for a polysaccharide antigen. Microscopic examination of a bronchoalveolar lavage specimen shows macrophages filled with oval cells that measure 1–5 μm and bud from a narrow base. Culture of the specimen on Sabouraud agar at 24°C grows molds composed of septate hyphae. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is a dimorphic fungus with a yeast form that has a narrow budding base, similar to what is seen here. This pathogen is acquired via inhalation and acute paracoccidioidomycosis would manifest with systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, chills, headache), which are seen in this patient. However, the yeast cells of Paracoccidioides spp. are typically 20–60 μm in size (larger than an erythrocyte) and form a characteristic captain's wheel formation. Moreover, acute paracoccidioidomycosis (juvenile paracoccidioidomycosis) typically affects children and adolescents and would cause lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and aplastic anemia, not pulmonary symptoms. Pulmonary symptoms only occur in the chronic form of paracoccidioidomycosis, which affects adult men 6–15 times more frequently than women (estrogen is protective against Paracoccidioides spp.). Finally, this pathogen is endemic to Central and South America, not the Mississippi delta.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue sample stained for fungi (methenamine silver stain)

Multiple large, round yeast cells are present. On some of the cells, narrow-necked budding can be seen, resulting in the characteristic “captain's wheel” formation (illustration; example indicated by green overlay).

This is the typical appearance of the budding yeasts causing paracoccidioidomycosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungus that is acquired via inhalation and appears as a yeast that buds from a narrow base. It can cause respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough, dyspnea) in immunocompromised patients and, in the case of hematogenous dissemination, results in excretion of a polysaccharide antigen (capsular antigen) in serum and urine. However, C. neoformans is a monomorphic fungus; it would not form hyphae. Also, C. neoformans, which measures 5–10 μm in size, is larger than the cells seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

C) INCORRECT:

Legionella pneumophila is a facultative intracellular pathogen; infection with this pathogen can result in systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, chills), lobar or atypical pneumonia (Legionnaires' disease), and a positive urine antigen test (in the case of infection with L. pneumophila serogroup 1). However, L. pneumophila is a bacterium, not a fungus; it grows on charcoal yeast agar enriched with iron and cysteine, not Sabouraud agar. Moreover, Legionnaires' disease would also result in diarrhea and/or neurological abnormalities (e.g., confusion, agitation), which are not seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis is a dimorphic fungus that is acquired via inhalation and coccidioidomycosis can manifest with symptoms of acute pneumonia (valley fever) and joint pain (desert rheumatism), both of which are seen here. However, bronchoalveolar lavage in pulmonary coccidioidomycosis would show large spherules (10–80 μm in size) with multiple endospores. Moreover, the disease is most commonly seen in the Southwestern US, not the Mississippi basin.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Coccidioides immitis in lung tissue (methenamine silver stain; high magnification)

Spherule (red circles) and endospore (green overlays) forms of Coccidioides immitis, a causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, can be seen.

E) INCORRECT:

Infection with the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus (aspergillosis) can manifest with cough, fever, and malaise, and tissue samples would show septate hyphae (with a characteristic 45° branching). Urine might also be positive for a polysaccharide antigen (e.g., galactomannan, beta-D-glucan) in the case of invasive aspergillosis. However, A. fumigatus is a monomorphic fungus; it does not have a yeast form, as seen here. Moreover, since aspergillosis is typically caused by chronic exposure to the fungus, symptoms usually have a gradual progression; acute invasive aspergillosis is less common and only occurs in immunocompromised patients.

F) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis jirovecii is an obligate intracellular fungus with an oval or disc-like appearance; immunocompromised patients who are infected with this pathogen can develop atypical pneumonia, symptoms of which are seen here. However, P. jirovecii is a monomorphic fungus and only has a yeast form; it does not form hyphae.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue infected with P. jirovecii (methenamine silver staining)

Six to eight spores grow within each cyst (darkly stained) and are released into the lung tissue when the cysts burst. The spores adhere to the alveoli and replicate.

G) CORRECT:

Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus endemic to the Mississippi and Ohio river valleys. Infection typically occurs via exposure to bird or bat droppings. Immunocompetent patients with this condition are usually asymptomatic but if a large inoculum of the pathogen is inhaled or the patient is immunocompromised (e.g., the patient has AIDS, transplanted organs, and/or takes immunosuppressive medications), atypical pneumonia (e.g., dry cough, dyspnea) and systemic symptoms (e.g., low-grade fever, malaise, joint pain) can occur. The best initial test in the case of suspected histoplasmosis, especially for patients who are acutely ill, is a urine or serum test for the galactomannan antigen of H. capsulatum. This test is less specific because of crossreaction with antigens of other fungi. A fungal culture of bronchoalveolar lavage is more specific but takes longer (up to 6 weeks). Localized pulmonary histoplasmosis is typically treated with itraconazole and disseminated histoplasmosis with amphotericin B.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2015)

H) INCORRECT:

Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus endemic to the Eastern and Central US (including the Mississippi basin). This pathogen is acquired via inhalation, and blastomycosis manifests as acute pneumonia with systemic symptoms, which is seen here. Urine might also be positive for a polysaccharide antigen in blastomycosis. However, the yeast forms of B. dermatitidis are as large as an erythrocyte (8–10 μm in size) and bud from a broad base; the bronchoalveolar lavage finding of small yeast cells that bud from a narrow base indicates a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (GMS stain)

Thick-walled fungi with single broad-based buds are visible.

This is the typical appearance of Blastomyces dermatitidis in yeast form (at body temperature, 37°C). At room temperature (∼ 23°C ), this dimorphic fungus exists in mold form.
questions.hint: Microbiological examination of the bronchoalveolar lavage shows a dimorphic fungus, which typically exists in a yeast form in body tissue (37°C) and in a hyphal form at room temperature (20–30°C). Microscopic findings also show that the yeast form of this pathogen is intracellular and smaller than an erythrocyte, which is 8–10 μm in size.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband for increasing confusion over the past 12 hours. Her husband reports that she has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus; she has not been able to refill her home insulin supply over the last 3 days because of insurance issues. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 115/60 mm Hg. She is confused and oriented only to person. Examination shows left periorbital swelling, mucopurulent rhinorrhea, and a black necrotic spot over her nose. There is discharge of the left eye with associated proptosis. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



 Na+

132 mEq/L


 Cl-

96 mEq/L


 K+

4.2 mEq/L


 HCO3-

16 mEq/L


 Glucose

520 mg/dL


 Ketones

positive


Urine ketones
positive


A CT scan of the face shows obliteration of the left ethmoid, maxillary, and sphenoid sinuses. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Rhizopus oryzae is the most commonly implicated organism, followed by Mucor species, in the pathophysiology of mucormycosis. Patients typically present with signs of a unilateral maxillofacial infection such as retro-orbital headache, facial pain, nasal discharge, and fever. Severe cases can also lead to altered levels of consciousness (indicative of cerebral involvement), eschars (due to microvascular occlusion and resulting tissue necrosis), and cranial nerve palsies. The presence of eschar is particularly concerning for this condition. This patient has several of these early and late signs and symptoms. Moreover, diabetic ketoacidosis is strongly implicated in the pathophysiology of this infection. The history of missed insulin doses combined with urine and serum ketones is diagnostic of ketoacidosis.
Image Description:

Bilateral edema of the eyelid and purulent exudation from both eyes is visible. There are spotted areas of necrotic eschar, especially close to the inner canthus of the right eye, on the right eyelid, and on the nose.

These findings, especially in an immunocompromised patient, suggest Mucorales infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic coccobacillus. With the advent of the Hib vaccine, the incidence of serious bacterial infection attributable to encapsulated strains of H. influenzae has dropped sharply. In developed nations, infection with unencapsulated strains still occurs but is usually mild, causing acute otitis media, conjunctivitis, or sinusitis in children. In developing nations, where vaccination is less common, encapsulated strains may still cause bacteremia, pneumonia, or acute epiglottitis. This adult has no indication of missed vaccinations and has a progressive, localized infection that is not frequently associated with H. influenzae.

C) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans is a common fungal species that exists as normal skin flora. In patients with diabetes, there is an increased risk of developing localized overgrowth of the fungus in the mouth, causing thrush. In immunocompromised patients, disseminated candidiasis or candidal esophagitis may develop. However, C. albicans is not known to cause necrotizing facial infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella pneumoniae is part of the normal bacterial flora of the body but can become an opportunistic pathogen; the presence of diabetes, especially with poor control, is a risk factor for infection with this bacterium. The most common sites of K. pneumoniae infection are the urinary tract (cystitis and pyelonephritis) and the lower respiratory tract (pneumonia). This patient is certainly at risk of developing an infection with this agent but the current presentation of necrotizing maxillofacial infection would be very unusual for K. pneumoniae.

E) INCORRECT:

Moraxella catarrhalis is common respiratory bacterium. Infection with this organism most commonly manifests with upper respiratory or otitis media symptoms. Severe, necrotizing infection, as described in this patient, would be extremely unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive coccus that classically forms clusters when viewed microscopically. This virulent bacterial species is associated with many infections; skin manifestations include cellulitis, impetigo, folliculitis, and even necrotizing fasciitis. The most common presentations are isolated skin abscesses in an adult or impetigo in a child. A necrotizing infection of the face would be very uncommon for this pathogen. Moreover, the presence of diabetic ketoacidosis and a newly formed eschar is more concerning for infection from a different organism.

G) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a highly virulent bacterial species. It is implicated in many infectious conditions and can be especially difficult to treat in cases of nosocomial or multidrug-resistant infections. With regard to the subpopulation of diabetic patients, Pseudomonas classically causes malignant otitis externa. This condition leads to severe ear pain, discharge from the ear canal, facial nerve palsy, and local extension to periauricular structures. Examination may show granulation tissue (often described as “sand-like”). Besides poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, other risk factors include advancing age and general immunosuppression. Despite her diabetes, this patient's presentation is inconsistent with malignant otitis externa.

H) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common gram-positive pathogenic bacterium. It is the most common cause of sinusitis, though the clinical presentation is generally mild and consists of rhinorrhea, facial tenderness (especially on palpation of the affected sinuses), and headache. Numerous other infectious conditions are attributable to this bacterium, including dermatologic infections (abscesses and cellulitis, most often). This patient is presenting with a severe, necrotizing skin infection in the setting of poorly controlled diabetes, altered sensorium, and an eschar. This constellation is very concerning for a more sinister infectious agent than S. pneumoniae.
questions.hint: This woman has a unilateral rhino-orbital-cerebral infection caused by a pathogen that is particularly common among patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.text: A biopsy is taken from the area of necrosis and direct microscopy reveals broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching. In addition to surgical debridement and aggressive blood glucose control, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Posaconazole is a broad-spectrum antifungal agent used in the treatment of infections caused by Aspergillus and Candida species. It may also be used as a second-line or salvage agent in patients with mucormycosis, but only if the first-line antifungal treatment is ineffective or not tolerated, or as stepdown therapy after control of the disease is achieved. A different therapy should be tried first.

B) INCORRECT:

Prednisone is a potent anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressant that is used to treat a variety of conditions. While corticosteroids may be used in the treatment of asthma or sinus disease related to allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, they are contraindicated for most invasive fungal infections, including mucormycosis.

C) CORRECT:

Rhinocerebral mucormycosis is an invasive, life-threatening infection that must be treated promptly and aggressively with surgical debridement and amphotericin B. Progression can be very rapid (within hours), and this patient's altered mental status and periorbital swelling should raise concern for orbital and cranial extension. Empirical treatment with amphotericin B should be started as soon as the diagnosis is suspected. Aggressive blood glucose control is also essential.

D) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is an antifungal agent used to treat infections caused by organisms including Candida, Cryptococcus neoformans, and dermatophytes. It is not effective in patients with mucormycosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Piperacillin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic with pseudomonal coverage. It may be used to treat ecthyma gangrenosum, a cutaneous infection that typically presents as a necrotic ulcer in immunocompromised patients. Piperacillin is not an effective treatment for mucormycosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) can be used to treat a variety of infectious organisms, including Nocardia species. Nocardia can also cause cellulitis, abscess formation, ulceration, and draining sinus tracts in immunosuppressed patients, but it appears as gram-positive, weakly acid-fast filaments on microscopy. TMP-SMX is not effective in the treatment of mucormycosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin can be used to treat various bacterial infections, including cutaneous anthrax, which can present with an ulcerating vesicle and black eschar formation, as well as fever and regional lymphadenopathy. While it can also involve the face or oropharynx, Bacillus anthracis is a rod-shaped, gram-positive aerobic bacterium, unlike the organism seen in this patient. Ciprofloxacin is not an effective treatment for mucormycosis.

H) INCORRECT:

Oxacillin is a penicillin antibiotic with intrinsic beta-lactamase resistance that is used to treat gram-positive aerobic infections, particularly methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus species. While it is commonly used for the treatment of bacterial skin and soft tissue infections, is not an effective treatment for mucormycosis.
questions.hint: The presence of broad, non-septate hyphae is consistent with the diagnosis of mucormycosis, an aggressive and invasive fungal infection. The medication indicated in patients with mucormycosis is nephrotoxic and can cause distal renal tubular acidosis.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of a progressively worsening rash on his buttocks for the last week. He cries during diaper changes and is more fussy than usual. Physical examination of the boy shows erythematous papules and plaques in the bilateral inguinal creases, on the scrotum, and in the gluteal cleft. Small areas of maceration are also present. A diagnosis is made, and treatment with topical clotrimazole is initiated. Microscopic examination of skin scrapings from this patient's rash is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Fruiting bodies with septate, acute-angle hyphae
Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Narrow budding, encapsulated yeast on India ink staining indicates Cryptococcus neoformans infection. Cryptococcus neoformans infection is primarily seen in immunocompromised patients and can cause pneumonia, cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, and brain abscesses. Cryptococcus neoformans is not associated with diaper rash.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

B) CORRECT:

Candida albicans appears as oval, budding yeast with pseudohyphae in skin scrapings of an infection. Candida albicans is part of the normal skin flora, but infection can occur when there is an imbalance that allows local Candida albicans overgrowth. Infants are often affected by Candida mucocutaneous infections in the anogenital region since overgrowth is facilitated by the prolonged damp and warm conditions of a diaper.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (200x magnification)

A cluster of yeast-like cells (arrowhead) is visible in the upper right corner of the image. Arising from this cluster are numerous pseudohyphae identifiable as long filamentous nonseptate structures (example indicated by a blue overlay). Asexual budding spores (blastospores; example indicated by red overlay) arise along the sides of the pseudohyphae. Thick-walled solitary circular chlamydospores (resting stage of Candida; example indicated by green overlay) arise from the tips of the pseudohyphae.

This coexistence of different morphological types (yeast cells, pseudohyphae, budding blastospores, and resting chlamydospores) is typical of Candida albicans.

C) INCORRECT:

Fruiting bodies with septate, acute-angle hyphae (45°) on tissue biopsy indicate Aspergillus fumigatus infection. Aspergillus fumigatus can cause allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), chronic pulmonary aspergillosis, invasive aspergillosis, and infective endocarditis. Although Aspergillus fumigatus can cause irritation of the skin in patients with ABPA, it is not associated with diaper rash.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Aspergillus fumigatus

Several buds are visible sprouting from the thread-like structure of the septate hyphae (green overlays). Buds are composed of a stalk (conidiophore; blue overlay) topped by a conidial head. The head consists of a central spherical vesicle (not visible here but indicated by yellow circle) surrounded by chains of prophialide (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and phialide projections (examples indicated by green arrowheads) with conidia tips (examples indicated by black arrowheads). The base is formed by a foot cell (red overlay).

D) INCORRECT:

Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells (captain's wheel) on KOH test (potassium hydroxide smear) indicates Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection is most often asymptomatic, but it can manifest with acute pneumonia, painful nasopharyngeal ulcerations, and verrucous skin lesions. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is not associated with diaper rash.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (methenamine silver stain)

A circular cell with round budding daughter cells can be seen in the center of the image. This appearance (“pilot's wheel”) is characteristic of Paracoccidioides species. Additional Paracoccidioides cells that do not have the classic appearance can be seen in the upper left.

E) INCORRECT:

Broad-based budding yeast on KOH test (potassium hydroxide smear) indicates Blastomyces dermatitidis infection. This patient has a diaper rash and no evidence of systemic disease (e.g., pneumonia, flulike symptoms), making a Blastomyces dermatitidis infection highly unlikely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (GMS stain)

Thick-walled fungi with single broad-based buds are visible.

This is the typical appearance of Blastomyces dermatitidis in yeast form (at body temperature, 37°C). At room temperature (∼ 23°C ), this dimorphic fungus exists in mold form.
questions.hint: This patient has typical signs of a diaper rash due to Candida albicans. It can be treated with a variety of topical antifungal agents such as clotrimazole.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of increasing confusion over the past 12 hours. His wife reports that he has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus. His temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F). He is confused and oriented only to person. Examination shows left periorbital swelling that is tender to palpation, mucopurulent rhinorrhea, and a black necrotic spot over the nose. There is discharge of the left eye with associated proptosis. A photomicrograph of a specimen obtained on biopsy of the left maxillary sinus is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans can cause systemic infections (disseminated candidiasis) in patients who are immunocompromised. However, it does not cause necrotizing facial infections. In patients with diabetes, Candida more commonly results in localized overgrowth (e.g., thrush). In addition, these organisms appear on histopathologic examination as budding yeast that may have pseudohyphae; the photomicrograph shows broad, nonseptate hyphae that branch at right angles.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (200x magnification)

A cluster of yeast-like cells (arrowhead) is visible in the upper right corner of the image. Arising from this cluster are numerous pseudohyphae identifiable as long filamentous nonseptate structures (example indicated by a blue overlay). Asexual budding spores (blastospores; example indicated by red overlay) arise along the sides of the pseudohyphae. Thick-walled solitary circular chlamydospores (resting stage of Candida; example indicated by green overlay) arise from the tips of the pseudohyphae.

This coexistence of different morphological types (yeast cells, pseudohyphae, budding blastospores, and resting chlamydospores) is typical of Candida albicans.

B) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae serotype b can cause invasive infections, but the prevalence of these infections has sharply decreased due to routine vaccination, and there is no indication of missed vaccinations in this patient. Nontypeable H. influenzae typically causes noninvasive infections such as sinusitis, conjunctivitis, and otitis media, unlike this patient's severe rhino-orbital-cerebral infection. In addition, these organisms appear on histopathologic examination as gram-negative rods; the photomicrograph shows broad, nonseptate hyphae that branch at right angles.

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa can cause ecthyma gangrenosum, a rapidly progressive, cutaneous infection that manifests with a necrotic ulcer. This condition often develops around the gluteal region but can less commonly affect the face. In addition, these organisms appear on histopathologic examination as gram-negative rods; the photomicrograph shows broad, nonseptate hyphae that branch at right angles.

D) CORRECT:

Rhizopus and Mucor species have broad, nonseptate hyphae that branch at right angles, as seen in the photomicrograph, and can cause mucormycosis. Diabetic ketoacidosis is a significant risk factor that predisposes to this condition, which typically manifests as a unilateral, invasive, maxillofacial infection with headache, facial pain, nasal discharge, and fever, as seen in this patient. Severe infections can lead to altered mental status (due to cerebral involvement), eschars (due to microvascular occlusion and resulting tissue necrosis), and cranial nerve palsies.

The diagnosis of mucormycosis is confirmed via identification of characteristic fungal organisms on histopathologic examination of biopsy tissue. Treatment involves surgical debridement and intravenous antifungal agents (e.g., amphotericin B).

E) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most commonly implicated organism in cases of sinusitis. Although it can also cause skin and soft tissue infections (e.g., abscesses, cellulitis), it does not typically result in severe, necrotizing infections. In addition, these organisms appear on histopathologic examination as gram-positive cocci; the photomicrograph shows broad, nonseptate hyphae that branch at right angles.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Streptococcus (Gram stain)

The chains of bluish-purple (gram positive) cocci seen on this Gram stain are characteristic of the genus Streptococcus.

F) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus fumigatus typically only causes systemic infections (e.g., invasive aspergillosis) in patients who are immunocompromised. However, it does not result in necrotizing facial infections. In addition, these organisms appear on histopathologic examination as monomorphic septate hyphae that branch at acute angles; the photomicrograph shows broad, nonseptate hyphae that branch at right angles.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of mitral valve vegetation (PAS stain; very high magnification)

A mycelium composed of PAS positive septate hyphae with dichotomous branching at a 30–45° angle is visible.

This is the classic finding of infection with Aspergillus spp., indicating Aspergillus endocarditis.

G) INCORRECT:

Blastomyces dermatitidis causes blastomycosis, which typically manifests as a pulmonary infection but can lead to ulcerative cutaneous lesions. It does not commonly result in necrotizing facial infections. In addition, these organisms appear on histopathologic examination as yeast with a broad base of attachment between buds and parent cells; the photomicrograph shows broad, nonseptate hyphae that branch at right angles.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (GMS stain)

Thick-walled fungi with single broad-based buds are visible.

This is the typical appearance of Blastomyces dermatitidis in yeast form (at body temperature, 37°C). At room temperature (∼ 23°C ), this dimorphic fungus exists in mold form.

H) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis jirovecii can cause pneumonia in patients who are immunocompromised; however, infections are typically asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. It does not result in necrotizing facial infections. In addition, these organisms appear on histopathologic examination as disc-shaped yeast; the photomicrograph shows broad, nonseptate hyphae that branch at right angles.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue infected with P. jirovecii (methenamine silver staining)

Six to eight spores grow within each cyst (darkly stained) and are released into the lung tissue when the cysts burst. The spores adhere to the alveoli and replicate.

I) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans generally only lead to systemic infections (e.g., cryptococcosis, cryptococcal meningoencephalitis) in patients who are immunocompromised. It does not typically cause necrotizing facial infections. In addition, these organisms appear on histopathologic examination as yeast with mucicarmine-positive capsules; the photomicrograph shows broad, nonseptate hyphae that branch at right angles.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.
questions.hint: This man has a rhino-orbital-cerebral infection caused by a pathogen that is most commonly seen in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of a nonpruritic rash on his right forearm. The rash began as pustules and progressed to form nodules and ulcers. He works as a gardener. Physical examination shows right axillary lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the patient's rash is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pasteurella multocida is a gram‑negative coccobacillus that causes cellulitis secondary to dog or cat bite wounds and not to gardening activity. Cellulitis would manifest with an erythematous skin lesion with poorly defined margins and lymphadenopathy but not with ulcerations. Furthermore, systemic symptoms (fever, chills, confusion) would be expected, and lesions tend to be painful rather than painless, as seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram‑negative bacteria typically found in water and humid conditions. It causes nosocomial infections and ecthyma gangrenosum, which is a rapidly progressive necrotic ulcer affecting the epidermis and dermis. However, ecthyma gangrenosum is typically seen in diabetics and immunocompromised patients and is not associated with gardening activities.
Image Description:

Two purpuric erythematous patches are visible. The large lesion has a necrotic center with an erythematous halo. The smaller lesion at the bottom right may represent an earlier stage.

These lesions are suggestive of ecthyma gangrenosum, which is typically caused by an infection by pseudomonas aeruginosa.

C) INCORRECT:

Bartonella henselae causes cat-scratch disease (CSD), which usually manifests with one or more papules and/or pustules and regional lymphadenopathy. However, it rarely ulcerates or forms nodules. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, malaise, myalgias, and/or loss of appetite are also common. Furthermore, CSD primarily affects children and adolescents.
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

D) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella granulomatis is a gram‑negative bacteria that produces granuloma inguinale, which typically presents with nodules that eventually ulcerate to form large, beefy-red lesions that bleed easily. However, those are typically found in the genital region, and regional lymph nodes would not be affected. Furthermore, granuloma inguinale is a sexually transmitted disease and is not associated with gardening.
Image Description:

Perianal region of a female patient with Klebsiella granulomatis infection

Multiple confluent, partially ulcerated papules are visible.

Diagnosis was confirmed via visualization of darkly staining Donovan bodies in biopsy crush preparations.

E) INCORRECT:

Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus endemic to Canada and eastern states of the US that is commonly found near lakes and rivers in wet soil and decaying wood. Blastomycosis can be transmitted by working with soil and cause pustules, nodules, ulcers, and regional lymphadenopathy. However, skin manifestations occur following dissemination of lung disease, which this patient has no signs of (e.g., coughing).
Image Description:

Dorsal surface of a left hand

An ulcerated, slightly raised lesion with a verrucous surface is visible close to the patient's knuckle.

This type of lesion suggests a cutaneous manifestation of Blastomyces dermatitidis infection caused by hematologic dissemination. Such infections are typically asymptomatic, or they manifest as pneumonia from the inhalation of spores. Since Blastomyces dermatitidis infection is rare, it is easily misdiagnosed as squamous cell cancer.

F) CORRECT:

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that causes cutaneous and disseminated sporotrichosis (the latter mainly in immunocompromised patients). It is associated with traumatic injury to the skin (e.g., thorn prick) and therefore often found in gardeners, landscapers, and berry pickers. Skin manifestations include pustules, nodules, ulcers, and ascending, suppurative lymphangitis. Oral itraconazole or potassium iodide is the first-line treatment for cutaneous infections with Sporothrix schenckii. Disseminated infections are treated with IV amphotericin B.
questions.hint: A biopsy of the lesion would show cigar-shaped buds.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of productive cough, fever, and lethargy. He also has several skin lesions over his body. His symptoms began 3 weeks after he returned from a camping trip in Kentucky. Three years ago, he underwent kidney transplantation for polycystic kidney disease. Current medications include sirolimus and prednisone. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Diffuse crackles are heard over the lung fields. There are 4 white, verrucous skin patches over his chest and upper limbs. A photomicrograph of a skin biopsy specimen from one of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum that is associated with bird or bat droppings and is most common in Mississippi and the Ohio river valleys. Patients may present with symptoms similar to the ones seen here, including cough, fever, and lethargy with skin lesions in disseminated disease, which typically affects immunocompromised individuals such as this patient. However, microscopic examination would reveal macrophages filled with histoplasma fungi rather than the large, thick-walled yeast with a single broad-based bud seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a soil specimen at 25°C (lactophenol cotton blue stain)

Numerous septated hyphae are visible throughout the image. The large, knobbly (tuberculated), dark blue spherical structures are the macroconidia. The small, smooth, pink spherical structures are the microconidia.

This is the typical appearance of Histoplasma capsulatum in mold (mycelial) form. At temperatures > 37°C, Histoplasma capsulatum exists in a yeast form.

B) INCORRECT:

Mucormycosis is a fungal infection caused by Mucor or Rhizopus spp. that typically affects immunocompromised and diabetic patients. Infection most commonly occurs in the sinuses, causing fever and headaches. Diabetic ketoacidosis facilitates the dissemination of the fungus and causes skin necrosis. However, microscopic examination would reveal irregular, broad, nonseptate hyphae branching at wide angles rather than the large, thick-walled yeast with a single broad-based bud seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of stomach tissue (H&E stain; 975x magnification)

A broad, nonseptate hypha can be seen branching into two hyphae at a wide angle of ∼ 90°.

Aseptate hyphae with unusually wide branching angles are characteristic features of mucormycosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Coccidioidomycosis is a fungal infection caused by Coccidioides immitis that is endemic to the southwestern United States and California. Patients with coccidioidomycosis may present with symptoms similar to those seen here, including cough, fever, and lethargy with skin lesions in immunocompromised individuals (erythema nodosum, erythema multiforme). However, microscopy would reveal dimorphic spherules filled with endospores rather than the large, thick-walled yeast with a single broad-based bud seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung biopsy specimen (H&E stain; very high magnification)

A thick-walled eosinophilic spherule (dashed outline) filled with endospores (arrow) and surrounded by a dense inflammatory infiltrate of neutrophils (arrowhead) can be seen in the center of the image.

These findings are suggestive of coccidioidomycosis, which is usually caused by the fungus Coccidioides immitis. The diagnosis was confirmed by culture of tissue samples.

D) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcosis is a fungal infection caused by Cryptococcus neoformans that is associated with exposure to pigeon droppings that primarily affects immunocompromised individuals. Similar to this patient, cryptococcosis can cause fever, cough, and lethargy with skin lesions specifically in solid organ transplant recipients. However, microscopic examination would reveal round yeasts of variables sizes that undergo narrow, unequal budding rather than the large, thick-walled yeast with a single broad-based bud seen here. Cryptococcus species are India ink positive because of the thick polysaccharide capsules.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes are visible, with the polysaccharide capsules appearing in darker blue.

E) CORRECT:

Blastomycosis is a fungal infection caused by species of the dimorphic fungus Blastomyces that is endemic to Central America and the central and eastern United States. Immunocompetent individuals are typically asymptomatic, with occasional pneumonia and flu-like symptoms that rarely disseminate further. Immunocompromised individuals, as this patient who underwent kidney transplantation, are at high risk for disseminated infection. Once disseminated, the fungus can cause skin, bone (lytic lesions), genitourinary (prostate, testes, and epididymis), and CNS pathology (meningitis and brain abscesses).
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2017)

F) INCORRECT:

Paracoccidioidomycosis is a fungal infection found virtually exclusively in Latin and Middle America. Although patients may present with symptoms similar to the ones of this patient, including cough, fever, and lethargy with skin lesions in cases of disseminated infections, microscopic examinations would show budding yeasts with captain's wheel formations rather than the large, thick-walled yeast with a single broad-based bud seen here. Moreover, this patient does not report having traveled to an area in which this disease is endemic.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (methenamine silver stain)

A circular cell with round budding daughter cells can be seen in the center of the image. This appearance (“pilot's wheel”) is characteristic of Paracoccidioides species. Additional Paracoccidioides cells that do not have the classic appearance can be seen in the upper left.

G) INCORRECT:

Aspergillosis is a fungal disease caused by species of Aspergillus, which are ubiquitous in nature. Infection typically manifests with fever, cough, and weakness and may cause skin lesions similar to the ones seen here in disseminated disease, which typically affects immunocompromised individuals such as this patient. However, microscopic examination would show fungi with monomorphic septate hyphae branching at 45 degrees rather than the large, thick-walled yeast with a single broad-based bud seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Aspergillus fumigatus

Several buds are visible sprouting from the thread-like structure of the septate hyphae (green overlays). Buds are composed of a stalk (conidiophore; blue overlay) topped by a conidial head. The head consists of a central spherical vesicle (not visible here but indicated by yellow circle) surrounded by chains of prophialide (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and phialide projections (examples indicated by green arrowheads) with conidia tips (examples indicated by black arrowheads). The base is formed by a foot cell (red overlay).
questions.hint: The skin biopsy shows a broad-based, dimorphic, budding fungus that was likely acquired during the patient's camping trip in Kentucky.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of fever, fatigue, dry cough, headache, and myalgia over the past week. Two days ago, he developed several painful oral lesions and difficulty swallowing. He underwent kidney transplantation 3 years ago. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F). Physical examination shows bilateral rales, hepatosplenomegaly, and multiple 1–2 cm ulcerative lesions with raised borders in the oral mucosa. A photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus fumigatus, an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised individuals, is found in the soil. Infection presents with fever, chest pain, cough, fatigue, and dyspnea. The disseminated form can include visceral organ involvement. Tissue biopsy shows 45°-angle branching septate hyphae with fruiting bodies.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Aspergillus fumigatus

Several buds are visible sprouting from the thread-like structure of the septate hyphae (green overlays). Buds are composed of a stalk (conidiophore; blue overlay) topped by a conidial head. The head consists of a central spherical vesicle (not visible here but indicated by yellow circle) surrounded by chains of prophialide (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and phialide projections (examples indicated by green arrowheads) with conidia tips (examples indicated by black arrowheads). The base is formed by a foot cell (red overlay).

B) INCORRECT:

Blastomyces dermatitidis is found in southern Canada and the central/eastern US and can cause flu-like symptoms, productive cough, chest pain, myalgias, and fever. The disseminated form, which occurs mainly in immunocompromised patients, involves the skin, CNS, and joints, causing verrucous and ulcerative lesions, meningitis, and lytic lesions, respectively. Disseminated B. dermatitidis does not typically involve the liver or the oral mucosa. Finally, the classic histologic findings are broad-based budding yeast.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (GMS stain)

Thick-walled fungi with single broad-based buds are visible.

This is the typical appearance of Blastomyces dermatitidis in yeast form (at body temperature, 37°C). At room temperature (∼ 23°C ), this dimorphic fungus exists in mold form.

C) CORRECT:

Disseminated Histoplasma capsulatum, which occurs in immunocompromised patients, is the cause of this patient's acute onset fever, fatigue, dry cough, headache, myalgias, hepatosplenomegaly, bilateral rales, and ulcerative oral lesions. The presence of ulcerative oral lesions is particular to this organism in relation to other fungal organisms. The liver biopsy shows the typical findings: macrophages filled with phagocytosed Histoplasma organisms.

In patients without immunocompromise, H. capsulatum presents subclinically or with a mild form limited to the lungs.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2015)

D) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans is found in pigeon excrement and presents with flu-like symptoms, cough, chest pain, dyspnea, and fever. The disseminated form may arise in patients with immunosuppression and can involve the skin, producing lesions of variable qualities, and the CNS, with multifocal intracerebral lesions causing increased intracranial pressure. Disseminated C. neoformans does not typically involve the liver, though. Tissue biopsy shows large, round yeast whereas this biopsy shows macrophages with engulfed, small organisms.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (mucicarmine stain; high magnification)

A widened alveolar septum with inflammatory cell infiltration (white arrowheads: macrophages; black arrowhead: neutrophil granulocyte) and yeasts of Cryptococcus neoformans (green overlay) are visible.

These findings are typical of pulmonary cryptococcosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is found in Central/Southern America. Infection presents with flu-like symptoms, productive cough, hemoptysis, dyspnea, facial lesions, and fever. The disseminated form, which occurs mainly in immunocompromised patients, involves the liver, spleen, lymph nodes, and bone marrow. Tissue biopsy shows yeast with a captain's wheel-like appearance, which is inconsistent with this patient's findings.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue sample stained for fungi (methenamine silver stain)

Multiple large, round yeast cells are present. On some of the cells, narrow-necked budding can be seen, resulting in the characteristic “captain's wheel” formation (illustration; example indicated by green overlay).

This is the typical appearance of the budding yeasts causing paracoccidioidomycosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Mucormycosis presents with severe pulmonary symptoms including productive cough, fever, and dyspnea. The most common disseminated form, which is especially prevalent in diabetics and immunocompromised patients, is rhinocerebral and involves the sinuses, eye, and facial bones, which can lead to CNS involvement. Disseminated mucormycosis does not typically involve the liver. Tissue biopsy demonstrates wide-angled branching of broad nonseptate hyphae.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of stomach tissue (H&E stain; 975x magnification)

A broad, nonseptate hypha can be seen branching into two hyphae at a wide angle of ∼ 90°.

Aseptate hyphae with unusually wide branching angles are characteristic features of mucormycosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis is found in the southwestern US and presents with flu-like symptoms, productive cough, chest pain, and fever. The disseminated form, which occurs mainly in immunocompromised patients, involves skin and bone, causing erythema nodosum, erythema multiforme, and lytic bone lesions. Disseminated C.immitis can further involve visceral organs, especially the liver. Tissue biopsy would show Cocci spherules filled with endospores, which is inconsistent with this patient's findings.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Coccidioides immitis in lung tissue (methenamine silver stain; high magnification)

Spherule (red circles) and endospore (green overlays) forms of Coccidioides immitis, a causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, can be seen.
questions.hint: This infection is most common in the Mississippi and Ohio river valley and occurs from exposure to bird or bat excrement.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of a productive cough, shortness of breath, and low-grade fever. He works as a farmer in southern Arizona. Physical examination shows multiple skin lesions with a dark blue center, pale intermediate zone, and red peripheral rim on the upper and lower extremities. There are diffuse crackles on the left side of the chest. An x-ray of the chest shows left basilar consolidation and left hilar lymphadenopathy. A photomicrograph of tissue obtained from a biopsy of the lung is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis is a fungus endemic to the southwestern United States that causes coccidioidomycosis after inhalation of spores released from soil. This condition typically manifests with flu-like illness, pneumonia, and skin lesions (e.g., erythema multiforme) in immunocompetent individuals, as seen in this case. C. immitis can cause disseminated disease in immunocompromised patients.

The systemic mycoses can be distinguished by histopathologic examination. Compared to a red blood cell, Coccidioides spherules are larger, Blastomyces buds are approximately the same size, and Histoplasma yeast forms are smaller.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2017)

B) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus fumigatus infection causes invasive aspergillosis, which also involves the lungs and causes cough, shortness of breath, and fever; chest x-ray can show focal consolidation. However, invasive disease primarily affects immunocompromised individuals. In addition, skin lesions are rare, and biopsy of affected tissue would show hyphae branching at acute angles.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Aspergillus fumigatus

Several buds are visible sprouting from the thread-like structure of the septate hyphae (green overlays). Buds are composed of a stalk (conidiophore; blue overlay) topped by a conidial head. The head consists of a central spherical vesicle (not visible here but indicated by yellow circle) surrounded by chains of prophialide (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and phialide projections (examples indicated by green arrowheads) with conidia tips (examples indicated by black arrowheads). The base is formed by a foot cell (red overlay).

C) INCORRECT:

Histoplasma capsulatum infection causes histoplasmosis, which can cause subacute pneumonia with hilar lymphadenopathy and erythema multiforme. However, symptomatic disease is uncommon in immunocompetent hosts. Biopsy of affected tissue would show macrophages filled with dimorphic fungi with septate hyphae. In addition, the fungus is endemic to the Mississippi and Ohio river valleys, not the southwestern United States.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Intracellular (examples indicated by white arrowheads) and extracellular (examples indicated by black arrowheads) forms of ovoid yeast-like organisms are visible.

The presence of these organisms is indicative of histoplasmosis. Diagnosis must be confirmed by culture and PCR array to determine the exact species (Histoplasma capsulatum in this case).

D) INCORRECT:

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection causes paracoccidioidomycosis. Though this condition has a chronic form that causes cough and dyspnea, chest x-ray would show fibrotic changes and biopsy of affected tissue would show organisms with a captain's wheel appearance. In addition, P. brasiliensis is endemic to Latin America, not the southwestern United States.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (methenamine silver stain)

A circular cell with round budding daughter cells can be seen in the center of the image. This appearance (“pilot's wheel”) is characteristic of Paracoccidioides species. Additional Paracoccidioides cells that do not have the classic appearance can be seen in the upper left.

E) INCORRECT:

Blastomyces dermatitidis infection causes blastomycosis, which can present with acute pneumonia and skin lesions. However, the typical skin lesions are verrucous and irregular, and hilar lymphadenopathy is uncommon. Biopsy of affected tissue would show broad-budding yeast. In addition, B. dermatitidis is endemic to the southeastern and central United States, not the southwest.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (GMS stain)

Thick-walled fungi with single broad-based buds are visible.

This is the typical appearance of Blastomyces dermatitidis in yeast form (at body temperature, 37°C). At room temperature (∼ 23°C ), this dimorphic fungus exists in mold form.

F) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans typically causes mucocutaneous infections; skin infection can cause pruritic, erythematous patches in intertriginous areas but does not cause erythema multiforme. Candida is a rare cause of pneumonia that develops due to hematogenous spread of a disseminated infection in an immunocompromised host.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (200x magnification)

A cluster of yeast-like cells (arrowhead) is visible in the upper right corner of the image. Arising from this cluster are numerous pseudohyphae identifiable as long filamentous nonseptate structures (example indicated by a blue overlay). Asexual budding spores (blastospores; example indicated by red overlay) arise along the sides of the pseudohyphae. Thick-walled solitary circular chlamydospores (resting stage of Candida; example indicated by green overlay) arise from the tips of the pseudohyphae.

This coexistence of different morphological types (yeast cells, pseudohyphae, budding blastospores, and resting chlamydospores) is typical of Candida albicans.
questions.hint: This man from the southwestern United States has pneumonia and erythema multiforme. The biopsy shows a spherule that contains endospores at the center of a granuloma.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fever, weakness, diffuse abdominal pain, and multiple lumps on his body. He has recently returned to the USA from a 3-month agricultural internship in South America. Physical examination shows enlarged superficial cervical and inguinal lymph nodes. There is tender hepatomegaly. A photomicrograph of a liver biopsy sample after methenamine silver staining is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Histoplasmosis most often manifests as an isolated pulmonary disease with dissemination virtually exclusively reserved for immunocompromised patients. It is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus with septate hyphae that is endemic to the Mississippi and Ohio river valleys and particularly associated with cave exploration and bird/bat droppings. Microscopic examination of infected tissue samples would show macrophages filled with the fungus.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Intracellular (examples indicated by white arrowheads) and extracellular (examples indicated by black arrowheads) forms of ovoid yeast-like organisms are visible.

The presence of these organisms is indicative of histoplasmosis. Diagnosis must be confirmed by culture and PCR array to determine the exact species (Histoplasma capsulatum in this case).

B) INCORRECT:

Blastomycosis causes isolated pulmonary disease or dissemination with extrapulmonary manifestations (e.g., osseous, cutaneous, or genitourinary involvement) in immunocompromised individuals. While this patient's recent journey to South America puts him at risk for fungal infections, Blastomyces dermatitidis is found in Central America and the Mississippi valley. Moreover, B. dermatidis presents with broad-based budding, not circular budding from a mother yeast.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (PAS stain)

Two large cells with thick walls are visible in the center of the image (green overlay). There is a single, broad-based area of contact between the two cells. These are budding Blastomyces dermatitidis yeast cells. The yeast cells are surrounded by numerous neutrophils.

Thick-walled fungi with single, broad-based buds are characteristic features of the yeast form of Blastomyces dermatitidis at body temperature (37°C). At room temperature (∼23°C), Blastomyces dermatitidis exists in a mold form.

C) INCORRECT:

Sporotrichosis (also known as “rose gardener disease” as the classic history involves a gardener being stuck with a rose thorn) is caused by Sporothrix schenckii. This infection manifests as ascending lymphangitis originating from erythematous nodules or ulcers at the site of initial infection. While this patient's recent agricultural internship puts him at risk for Sporothrix contraction, lymphadenopathy of two distinct regions without signs of ascending infection would not be expected. Moreover, microscopic evaluation of Sporothrix shows a cigar-shaped budding yeast, not the so-called captain's wheel formation as seen on this microphotograph.
Image Description:

Microscopy of a fungal culture at 25°C (lactophenol cotton blue stain)
Culture specimen obtained from a skin ulcer.

Numerous septated hyphae are seen.
Oval spores (conidia) are connected to the hyphae with narrow stems.
The buds are arranged in rosette-like clusters at the tips of the hyphae.

This is the typical appearance of the mold (mycelial) form of the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.
(At body temperature or temperatures > 37°C, Sporothrix schenckii exists in a yeast form, with characteristic cigar-shaped yeast cells.)

D) INCORRECT:

Sleeping sickness, also known as African trypanosomiasis, is transmitted by the Tsetse fly and is caused by the protozoa Trypanosoma brucei. The infection first presents with intermittent, spiking fevers, joint pain, and significant lymphadenopathy (especially in the neck) and can later progress to a central nervous system phase ranging from confusion to coma. Although this patient has lymphadenopathy, sleeping sickness does not cause hepatomegaly, is not commonly found in South America, and is diagnosed upon visualizing trypanosomes on a Giemsa-stained peripheral blood smear.
Image Description:

Blood smear (Giemsa stain)

Extracellular trypanosomes (Trypanosoma brucei) are visible with a typical streamlined and tapered shape and a flagellum that arises from the basal body.

E) INCORRECT:

Malaria can be attributed to several protozoan species but Plasmodium vivax is the most common. The infection presents with cyclic fevers (usually corresponding to a 48 hour cycle) and splenomegaly with findings of hemolytic anemia on further investigation. Although P. vivax is endemic to parts of South America, it does not cause lymphadenopathy or tender hepatomegaly. Furthermore, diagnosis is made with Giemsa-stained peripheral blood smear showing trophozoites (ring forms) or red stippling in erythrocytes.
Image Description:

Red blood cell inclusions in a patient with malaria

A large ring-like inclusion within erythrocyte in the center of the slide is an immature trophozoite. Thick, dark purple, ring‑shaped inclusions and fine dotting within erythrocytes (i.e., "Schüffner granules") are characteristic of infection with Plasmodium vivax or P. ovale.

F) CORRECT:

Paracoccidioidomycosis often presents acutely with hepatomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and nonspecific constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever), all of which are present in this patient. It is caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, which is endemic to South America. The microscopic visualization of multiple budding yeasts deriving from a large, round mother yeast is classic for this organism and confirms the diagnosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue sample stained for fungi (methenamine silver stain)

Multiple large, round yeast cells are present. On some of the cells, narrow-necked budding can be seen, resulting in the characteristic “captain's wheel” formation (illustration; example indicated by green overlay).

This is the typical appearance of the budding yeasts causing paracoccidioidomycosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Aspergillosis is caused by the organism Aspergillus fumigatus. It most typically presents with cough, wheezing, chest pain, and fever. A. fumigatus may cause other conditions, including allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergilloma formation, and life-threatening invasive aspergillosis. Extrapulmonary manifestations like hepatomegaly and lymphadenopathy are not associated with any of these conditions. Moreover, tissue biopsy would show septate hyphae branching at acute angles.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Aspergillus fumigatus

Several buds are visible sprouting from the thread-like structure of the septate hyphae (green overlays). Buds are composed of a stalk (conidiophore; blue overlay) topped by a conidial head. The head consists of a central spherical vesicle (not visible here but indicated by yellow circle) surrounded by chains of prophialide (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and phialide projections (examples indicated by green arrowheads) with conidia tips (examples indicated by black arrowheads). The base is formed by a foot cell (red overlay).

H) INCORRECT:

Visceral leishmaniasis is an infection caused by the protozoa Leishmania donovani. The organism invades the visceral organs, leading to hepatosplenomegaly and bone marrow failure (causing pancytopenia and relative immunocompromise). The condition does not, however, cause notable lymphadenopathy as is seen in this patient. Moreover, the gold standard for diagnosis is microscopic visualization of splenic biopsy showing amastigotes within macrophages.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow tissue specimen (Giemsa stain, very high magnification)

Dark purple, intracellular Leishmania parasites (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible within a histiocyte (blue overlay).

This finding suggests visceral leishmaniosis. However, the diagnosis should be confirmed by PCR or serology.

N: neutrophil; M: myeloid precursor cell; Eb: erythroblast

I) INCORRECT:

Coccidiomycosis can present as an acute pulmonary disease or a disseminated condition with systemic symptoms (e.g., erythema nodosum or erythema multiforme). While nonspecific symptoms like fever and weakness, as seen in this patient, would also be found with coccidioidomycosis, lymphadenopathy and hepatomegaly would not be expected. The causative organism, Coccidioides immitis, is endemic to the southwestern United States (but not South America) and appears microscopically as spherules filled with endospores.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E stain, medium power magnification)

A thick-walled spherule (yellow overlay) is visible near the center of an inflammatory granuloma (blue overlay). The spherule contains multiple endospores.

This histological appearance suggests pulmonary coccidioidomycosis. The diagnosis should be confirmed by culture and serological tests (IgM and IgG antibodies).
questions.hint: This patient's recent travel to South America raises concern for infection with an endemic organism. The photomicrograph shows large, round mother yeasts cells with multipolar budding yeasts (blastospores), resembling a ship's steering wheel, pointing to a fungal etiology.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, cough, and chest pain. Physical examination shows diffuse inspiratory crackles over the left lung field. An x-ray of the chest shows hilar lymphadenopathy and well-defined nodules with central calcifications. Urine studies show the presence of a polysaccharide antigen. A biopsy specimen of the lung shows cells with basophilic, crescent-shaped nuclei and pericellular halos located within macrophages. This patient's history is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treatment with inhaled glucocorticoids is an important risk factor for developing thrush (oropharyngeal infection with Candida albicans). This condition is not associated with pneumonia, lymphadenopathy, or the biopsy and antigen findings seen in this case. In addition, the characteristic lesions of thrush are white, oropharyngeal patches that show budding yeast and pseudohyphae on KOH preparation, not intracellular organisms.
Image Description:

Typical rod-like, budding structure of Candida albicans (red overlay).

B) INCORRECT:

A recent visit to the Arizona desert is a risk factor for infection with Coccidioides immitis, a dimorphic fungus endemic to the deserts of the southwestern United States, Mexico, and Central and South America. Pulmonary coccidioidomycosis (valley fever) can cause symptoms of acute pneumonia and manifest with lymphadenopathy on chest x-ray, which is seen here. However, it does not explain the antigen findings seen in this case. Additional manifestations of coccidioidomycosis would include arthralgia (“desert rheumatism”) and erythema nodosum or multiforme (“desert bumps”), which this patient does not have. Finally, microscopic evaluation of a biopsy would show spherules containing endospores, not intracellular organisms.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Coccidioides immitis in lung tissue (methenamine silver stain; high magnification)

Spherule (red circles) and endospore (green overlays) forms of Coccidioides immitis, a causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, can be seen.

C) INCORRECT:

A recent trip to Brazil is a risk factor for infection with Paracoccidioides spp., a dimorphic fungus endemic to South and Central America. Paracoccidioidomycosis causes pneumonia but not the antigen findings seen in this case. Additional manifestations include mucosal ulcerations and cervical (not hilar) lymphadenopathy. Biopsy would show budding yeast with a captain's wheel appearance, not intracellular organisms.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (methenamine silver stain)

A circular cell with round budding daughter cells can be seen in the center of the image. This appearance (“pilot's wheel”) is characteristic of Paracoccidioides species. Additional Paracoccidioides cells that do not have the classic appearance can be seen in the upper left.

D) INCORRECT:

Outbreaks of blastomycosis are often associated with recreational activities near lakes and rivers or exposure to beaver dams, particularly in the eastern United States and Mississippi River valley. This condition can cause pneumonia and flu-like symptoms but does not cause hilar lymphadenopathy, calcified nodules, or positive polysaccharide antigen. Blastomycosis typically manifests with verrucous skin lesions and genitourinary or CNS involvement. Biopsy of affected tissue would show broad-based budding, not intracellular organisms.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (GMS stain)

Thick-walled fungi with single broad-based buds are visible.

This is the typical appearance of Blastomyces dermatitidis in yeast form (at body temperature, 37°C). At room temperature (∼ 23°C ), this dimorphic fungus exists in mold form.

E) INCORRECT:

Previous mycobacterial infection is a risk factor for pulmonary aspergillosis (aspergilloma) due to colonization of pre-existing lung cavities by inhaled Aspergillus spores. Pulmonary aspergillosis can manifest with fever, cough, and respiratory distress but would be unlikely to cause calcified nodules, hilar lymphadenopathy, or the antigen findings seen in this case. In addition, biopsy of affected tissue would show acute-angle septate hyphae on staining, not intracellular organisms.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

There are numerous elongated, septated hyphae (examples indicated by blue overlay) of uniform diameter and with dichotomous branching at approx. 45° angles.

This is the typical appearance of Aspergillus. A culture is required to determine the exact Aspergillus species.

F) CORRECT:

Bat and bird droppings can carry Histoplasma capsulatum, particularly in endemic areas (e.g., the Ohio and Mississippi river valleys). Inhalation of the fungus causes histoplasmosis, a condition that manifests with primary pulmonary disease or disseminated disease, especially in patients who are immunocompromised.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Intracellular (examples indicated by white arrowheads) and extracellular (examples indicated by black arrowheads) forms of ovoid yeast-like organisms are visible.

The presence of these organisms is indicative of histoplasmosis. Diagnosis must be confirmed by culture and PCR array to determine the exact species (Histoplasma capsulatum in this case).
questions.hint: This woman has pneumonia (fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, cough, chest pain, crackles), hilar lymphadenopathy, a polysaccharide antigen in the urine, and a biopsy specimen of the lung that shows yeast cells within macrophages, all of which are features of Histoplasma capsulatum infection.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the military physician because of a 2-day history of fever, joint pain, dry cough, chest pain, and a painful red rash on her lower legs. Two weeks ago, she returned from military training in Southern California. She appears ill. Her temperature is 39°C (102.1°F). Physical examination shows diffuse inspiratory crackles over all lung fields and multiple tender erythematous nodules over the anterior aspect of both legs. A biopsy specimen of this patient's lungs is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Spherules filled with endospores on culture are a histological hallmark of coccidioidomycosis. Transmission of the disease is generally due to inhalation of fungal spores from contaminated soil. The disease typically presents with pneumonia and may also show extrapulmonary symptoms affecting the skin (desert bumps), CNS (meningitis), or joints (desert rheumatism).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E stain, medium power magnification)

A thick-walled spherule (yellow overlay) is visible near the center of an inflammatory granuloma (blue overlay). The spherule contains multiple endospores.

This histological appearance suggests pulmonary coccidioidomycosis. The diagnosis should be confirmed by culture and serological tests (IgM and IgG antibodies).

B) INCORRECT:

Non-septate hyphae with wide-angle branching is suggestive of Mucor and Rhizopus, two genera of molds that are ubiquitous in decaying vegetation and soil. Mucormycosis usually causes facial symptoms such as invasive chronic sinusitis, orbital cellulitis, or black necrotic eschar, but not pneumonia and erythematous nodules. Furthermore, it usually affects patients with diabetes mellitus and immunocompromised individuals.
Image Description:

Microscopy of heart valve tissues (Methenamine silver stain)

Long Ribbon-like structures can be observed (red overlay). They are wide and not septated.


These are the characteristic features of Mucor pusillus.

C) INCORRECT:

Broad-based budding yeast is characteristic of blastomycosis, a fungal infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, which typically causes pneumonia and skin lesions (verrucous lesions, granulomatous nodules) similar to the findings in this patient. However, this fungus is endemic to the Southeastern and Central US, the Midwest, and Canadian states near the Great Lakes, not to Southern California.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (PAS stain)

Two large cells with thick walls are visible in the center of the image (green overlay). There is a single, broad-based area of contact between the two cells. These are budding Blastomyces dermatitidis yeast cells. The yeast cells are surrounded by numerous neutrophils.

Thick-walled fungi with single, broad-based buds are characteristic features of the yeast form of Blastomyces dermatitidis at body temperature (37°C). At room temperature (∼23°C), Blastomyces dermatitidis exists in a mold form.

D) INCORRECT:

Oval, budding yeast with pseudohyphae is characteristic of Candida, a type of yeast (fungus) that appears almost universally in low numbers on healthy skin and mucosa as a commensal organism. Candida usually causes oral thrush, candida esophagitis, or vaginal yeast infection in immunocompromised individuals. Pneumonia or erythematous nodules would not be expected.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of fungus germination (KOH preparation, 600x)

Mother cells (blastospores; green overlay) produce a hyphal outgrowth of germ tubes (budding; dashed red outline).

Budding is suggestive of active candida infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Septate hyphae with acute-angle branching is characteristic of Aspergillus, a ubiquitous genus of fungus. Aspergillus can cause pneumonia. However, it usually affects patients who are immunocompromised or susceptible to infection due to preexisting conditions (e.g. tuberculosis). Moreover, erythematous nodules would not be expected.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Aspergillus fumigatus

Several buds are visible sprouting from the thread-like structure of the septate hyphae (green overlays). Buds are composed of a stalk (conidiophore; blue overlay) topped by a conidial head. The head consists of a central spherical vesicle (not visible here but indicated by yellow circle) surrounded by chains of prophialide (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and phialide projections (examples indicated by green arrowheads) with conidia tips (examples indicated by black arrowheads). The base is formed by a foot cell (red overlay).

F) INCORRECT:

Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells is characteristic of paracoccidioidomycosis, a fungal infection caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, which is most commonly found in Central and South America but not in southwestern parts of the US. Infected patients may present with pneumonia and verrucous skin lesions but usually do not develop symptoms.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue sample stained for fungi (methenamine silver stain)

Multiple large, round yeast cells are present. On some of the cells, narrow-necked budding can be seen, resulting in the characteristic “captain's wheel” formation (illustration; example indicated by green overlay).

This is the typical appearance of the budding yeasts causing paracoccidioidomycosis.
questions.hint: This patient's features of acute pneumonia (dry cough, chest pain, fever), arthralgia, and tender erythematous nodules should raise concern for infection with Coccidioides, a pathogenic fungus endemic to the southwestern parts of the United States.

questions.text: An investigator is studying growth patterns of various fungal pathogens. Incubation of an isolated fungus at 25°C shows branching hyphae with rosettes of conidia under light microscopy. After incubation at 37°C, microscopic examination of the same organism instead shows smooth, white colonies with rounded, elongated cells. Infection with the investigated pathogen is most likely to cause which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcosis is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, a yeast with a thick polysaccharide capsule and narrow, unequal budding. It is not dimorphic and has no hyphal form. Microscopic diagnosis of this fungus can be made with specialized stains, such as mucicarmine, that bind the polysaccharide capsule.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

B) INCORRECT:

Aspergillosis is caused by fungi of the genus Aspergillus, none of which are a dimorphic fungus. Regardless of the incubating temperature, microscopy would reveal septate hyphae branching at 45° and conidia in radiating chains. Yeast forms would not be seen.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

There are numerous elongated, septated hyphae (examples indicated by blue overlay) of uniform diameter and with dichotomous branching at approx. 45° angles.

This is the typical appearance of Aspergillus. A culture is required to determine the exact Aspergillus species.

C) INCORRECT:

Candidiasis is caused by the dimorphic fungus Candida albicans, which appears as a budding yeast with pseudohyphae when cultured at 20°C. Septated and branching hyphae, oval conidia, and cigar-shaped yeast forms are not characteristic of C. albicans.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (200x magnification)

A cluster of yeast-like cells (arrowhead) is visible in the upper right corner of the image. Arising from this cluster are numerous pseudohyphae identifiable as long filamentous nonseptate structures (example indicated by a blue overlay). Asexual budding spores (blastospores; example indicated by red overlay) arise along the sides of the pseudohyphae. Thick-walled solitary circular chlamydospores (resting stage of Candida; example indicated by green overlay) arise from the tips of the pseudohyphae.

This coexistence of different morphological types (yeast cells, pseudohyphae, budding blastospores, and resting chlamydospores) is typical of Candida albicans.

D) INCORRECT:

Coccidiomycosis is caused by Coccidioides, a dimorphic fungus that may also grow with septated hyphae. Instead of smooth, white colonies with rounded, elongated cells, the characteristic microscopic finding is a spherule filled with endospores of Coccidioides.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Coccidioides immitis in lung tissue (methenamine silver stain; high magnification)

Spherule (red circles) and endospore (green overlays) forms of Coccidioides immitis, a causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, can be seen.

E) CORRECT:

Sporothrix schenckii, which causes sporotrichosis, is most likely the fungus in question. As a dimorphic fungus, Sporothrix exists in yeast or hyphal forms depending on the surrounding temperature. At 25°C, it takes on its hyphal form, with septate branching hyphae and oval conidia. Clusters of these conidia may appear as rosettes. However, when grown at 37°C, microscopic evaluation reveals a cigar-shaped budding yeast. The fungus feeds on decaying plants and Infection occurs after a penetrating skin injury, e.g., from a thorn prick, explaining its prevalence in gardeners and similar workers. Sporotrichosis initially manifests as a pustule or ulcer that progresses to ascending lymphangitis.
Image Description:

Microscopy of a fungal culture at 25°C (lactophenol cotton blue stain)
Culture specimen obtained from a skin ulcer.

Numerous septated hyphae are seen.
