Oval spores (conidia) are connected to the hyphae with narrow stems.
The buds are arranged in rosette-like clusters at the tips of the hyphae.

This is the typical appearance of the mold (mycelial) form of the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.
(At body temperature or temperatures > 37°C, Sporothrix schenckii exists in a yeast form, with characteristic cigar-shaped yeast cells.)
questions.hint: The isolated organism exhibits fungal dimorphism. One of the characteristic clinical features in infected patients is ascending lymphangitis.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old military nurse with Crohn disease comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of fever, fatigue, dry cough, headache, and myalgia. During this period, he has also had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss. One week ago, he developed several painful oral lesions and difficulty swallowing. He serves at a military base in Ohio. Current medications include prednisone and infliximab. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), respirations are 20/min, pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 115/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diffuse bilateral crackles, hepatosplenomegaly, and multiple 1–2 cm ulcerative lesions with raised borders in the oral mucosa. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.0 g/dL


Erythrocyte count
3.0 million/mm3



Leukocyte count
4000/mm3 



Platelet count
100,000/mm3



Serum



AST
112 U/L


ALT
96 U/L


Results of a combined HIV antigen/antibody testing and an interferon-γ release assay are negative. An x-ray of the chest shows hilar lymphadenopathy with central calcification and multiple well-defined pulmonary nodules measuring 1–10 mm. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Amphotericin B is the best initial pharmacotherapy for disseminated histoplasmosis. Treatment with amphotericin B is given for 1–2 weeks and then followed by treatment with itraconazole for at least 12 months. For patients who are immunosuppressed and have only mild to moderate symptoms, treatment with itraconazole alone is appropriate. Patients who are immunocompetent typically only develop mild pulmonary disease and can be treated supportively.

Pulmonary findings of histoplasmosis and sarcoidosis can be very similar (e.g., pulmonary nodules, hilar lymphadenopathy). Histoplasmosis should be ruled out in endemic regions before starting corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive drugs if sarcoidosis is suspected.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2015)

B) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is used to treat Legionnaires' disease, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles). However, this condition typically manifests with diffuse interstitial infiltrates, not hilar lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules. In addition, Legionnaires' disease does not cause oral ulcers or hepatosplenomegaly. Levofloxacin is not used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is used to treat Pneumocystis pneumonia, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles). However, this condition typically manifests with diffuse interstitial infiltrates, not hilar lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules. In addition, Pneumocystis pneumonia does not cause oral ulcers or hepatosplenomegaly. TMP-SMX is not used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Flucytosine, in combination with amphotericin B, is used to treat cryptococcosis, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles, pulmonary nodules). However, this condition does not cause oral ulcers or hepatosplenomegaly. Flucytosine is not used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Caspofungin is used to treat invasive candidiasis, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and liver involvement (e.g., increased serum transaminases). However, this condition does not cause oral ulcers and only rarely affects the lungs. Caspofungin is not used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Voriconazole is a first-line treatment for invasive aspergillosis, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles, pulmonary nodules). However, this condition does not cause oral ulcers or hepatosplenomegaly and only rarely causes hilar lymphadenopathy. Voriconazole is not typically used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.
questions.hint: This patient takes immunosuppressive medications and has nonspecific constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss), oral ulcers, hepatosplenomegaly, pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles, hilar lymphadenopathy, well-defined pulmonary nodules), pancytopenia, and increased transaminase levels. These findings, in combination with living in an area endemic for Histoplasma capsulatum (Ohio), are consistent with a diagnosis of disseminated histoplasmosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of intermittent fevers, productive cough, and shortness of breath. Three weeks ago he was treated with amoxicillin-clavulanate and azithromycin, which did not improve his symptoms. He is also worried because he has noticed “some new bumps on his skin”. He lives in upstate New York along the Mohawk River. He has rheumatoid arthritis. He does not smoke cigarettes. His medications include methotrexate and a multivitamin. His temperature is 38.1ºC (100.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/75 mm Hg. Diffuse crackles are heard over both lung fields. Skin examination shows multiple, white, verrucous papules and nodules on the thighs. A CT scan of the chest shows bilateral tree-in-bud opacities in the lower lobes. A biopsy of a skin nodule shows pyogranulomatous inflammation and round yeast cells. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP pneumonia) is an opportunistic pulmonary infection that manifests with fever, cough, and dyspnea resistant to standard antibiotic treatment, all of which are seen here. However, PCP pneumonia rarely causes cutaneous manifestations. Moreover, PCP pneumonia is almost exclusively seen in immunocompromised patients (e.g., patients with AIDS). A biopsy would show disc-shaped yeast cells rather than round yeast cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungus that causes cryptococcosis, a condition that can manifest as pneumonia with extrapulmonary symptoms (including nodular skin lesions), which this patient has. However, Cryptococcus neoformans primarily affects patients who are immunocompromised (e.g., patients with AIDS). Moreover, Cryptococcus neoformans more commonly causes cryptococcal meningitis, which is not seen here.

C) CORRECT:

Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus endemic to the eastern and central United States that causes blastomycosis. This infection most often affects patients who are immunosuppressed or immunocompromised but, unlike most other dimorphic fungal infections, it can cause disseminated disease even in immunocompetent individuals. Blastomycosis typically manifests as pneumonia with extrapulmonary symptoms, which can involve the skin (e.g., verrucous skin lesions and granulomatous nodules, as seen in this patient), genitourinary system (e.g., prostatitis), central nervous system (e.g., meningitis and brain abscesses), and skeletal system (e.g., osteolytic lesions).

Patients who have pulmonary or extrapulmonary blastomycosis that does not affect the central nervous system can be treated with oral azoles (e.g., itraconazole). Severe infection, including cases in which the central nervous system is involved, should be treated with amphotericin B.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2017)

D) INCORRECT:

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that causes sporotrichosis. Although this condition usually manifests with localized disease, it can cause disseminated disease in patients who are immunosuppressed or immunocompromised. However, sporotrichosis typically develops after a penetrating skin injury (e.g., from a thorn) and manifests with a pustule or ulcer that progresses to ascending lymphangitis; pulmonary involvement is rare.

E) INCORRECT:

Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus endemic to the eastern and central United States that causes (disseminated) histoplasmosis, which can manifest as pneumonia with extrapulmonary symptoms (including nodular skin lesions). However, this condition primarily affects patients who are immunocompromised (e.g., patients with AIDS or transplant recipients). A biopsy would show small yeast cells contained within macrophages.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2015)

F) INCORRECT:

Paracoccidioides lutzii is a dimorphic fungus that causes paracoccidioidomycosis, a systemic fungal infection that classically manifests as pneumonia with extrapulmonary symptoms (including nodular skin lesions), which this patient has. However, this fungus is endemic to Latin America, not the eastern and central United States.

G) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus fumigatus is a fungus that causes pulmonary aspergillosis, a condition that can manifest with fever, cough, and dyspnea, all of which are seen here. However, cutaneous manifestations of aspergillosis are uncommon. Moreover, a biopsy would show a mold, not yeast cells.

H) INCORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis is a dimorphic fungus that causes disseminated coccidioidomycosis, a condition that can manifest as pneumonia with extrapulmonary symptoms (including nodular skin lesions), which this patient has. However, disseminated coccidioidomycosis primarily affects patients who are immunocompromised (e.g., patients with AIDS). Moreover, Coccidioides immitis is endemic to the southwestern United States, not the eastern and central United States.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2017)
questions.hint: This patient has subacute pneumonia that has not improved with antibiotic therapy. His extrapulmonary manifestations (cutaneous lesions), imaging findings (tree-in-bud opacities in the lower lobes), and biopsy findings (round yeast cells) are characteristic of a disseminated infection caused by a fungus endemic to the eastern and central United States. This patient's infection has disseminated even though he is not significantly immunocompromised (at normal doses, methotrexate has immunomodulatory effects but does not result in severe immunosuppression).

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male missionary reports one month of a nonproductive cough that began 5 days after he returned from a trip to Nicaragua. The cough is associated with fevers, chills, night sweats, myalgias, and mild shortness of breath. The patient reports no exposures to wild animals and no new sexual contacts, but he did stay in a hotel that was being remodeled.
The patient’s vital signs are normal, and his physical examination is unremarkable. CT of the chest is obtained (figure). A subsequent lung biopsy reveals necrotizing granulomatous pneumonitis with numerous fungal organisms.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aspergillosis is almost always seen in immunocompromised patients. It is generally a more indolent disease than histoplasmosis and has larger nodules, with an associated halo.

B) INCORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis is also endemic to certain areas of Central and South America but is less prevalent than Histoplasma. Chest imaging is more likely to reveal a focal opacity, reticulonodular changes, or thin-walled, apical cavities.

C) INCORRECT:

Blastomycosis is uncommon in Central and South America.

D) CORRECT:

Histoplasma capsulatum is endemic in Central and South America, so acute histoplasmosis should be on the differential diagnosis for travelers with new pulmonary symptoms who return from those regions.

Acute histoplasmosis usually manifests as a flulike illness characterized by high-grade fever, chills, headache, nonproductive cough, and fatigue. Chest imaging often reveals diffuse reticulonodular infiltrates. Symptoms typically occur 1 to 3 weeks after exposure, and most affected patients recover spontaneously within 3 weeks. Treatment is usually unnecessary for mild-to-moderate disease. If symptoms last more than one month, itraconazole (200 mg three times daily for 3 days, then 200 mg once or twice daily for 6 to 12 weeks) is recommended.

Key learning point: The most likely acute pulmonary fungal infection in a traveler returning from Central or South America is histoplasmosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is endemic in northeastern South America and in Central America. Paracoccidioides typically causes an asymptomatic primary pulmonary infection, but an acute disseminated infection may occur. Acute disseminated infections account for fewer than 10% of cases and are rare in adults over age 30.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman is hospitalized with a one-month history of low-grade fevers, chills, weight loss, and cough that produces yellow sputum. She was recently treated with a course of azithromycin as an outpatient but reports no improvement in her symptoms.
She has lived in Indiana her whole life and has never traveled outside the United States. She has worked as a middle school teacher since age 25; she has never smoked or had a positive tuberculin skin test.
Her chest radiograph reveals a single, round opacity in the right lower lobe.
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s one-month history of low-grade fevers, chills, weight loss, and cough productive of yellow sputum is consistent with chronic pneumonia. The most common cause of chronic pneumonia is Mycobacterium tuberculosis, but alternative causes also exist, and the most common of these is infection with an endemic fungus (e.g., blastomycosis, histoplasmosis, or coccidioidomycosis). Diagnosis of fungal infection is best made with antigen testing (for Histoplasma or Blastomyces) or antibody testing. In this case, a single, rounded opacity on chest radiograph in a patient from Indiana is most consistent with histoplasmosis or blastomycosis.

Key learning point: For a patient with no exposure to tuberculosis, the most common cause of chronic pneumonia is fungal infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Influenza infection causes acute pneumonia and would manifest with days, not weeks, of symptoms. Thus, influenza nasal swab testing would not be appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Although open lung biopsy is occasionally required to diagnose a chronic pneumonia, it is invasive and should be deferred unless noninvasive tests are unrevealing. Prior to an open lung biopsy, sputum studies and bronchoscopy should be performed.

D) INCORRECT:

Legionella infection causes acute pneumonia and would manifest with days, not weeks, of symptoms. Thus, Legionella urinary antigen would not be appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

If there is concern for tuberculosis, sputum stain and culture for acid-fast bacilli would be appropriate to diagnose active infection. A tuberculin skin test, which is used to diagnose latent tuberculosis infection, would not be helpful.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man with a history of well-controlled hypertension presents with persistent cough, malaise, and night sweats. He resides permanently in New Mexico and has had the symptoms for 6 weeks despite two courses of antibiotics, first with azithromycin and then with levofloxacin. His only other medication is lisinopril.
The patient has a temperature of 37.8°C and an oxygen saturation of 92% while breathing ambient air. Physical examination reveals faint inspiratory crackles in his right lower lung field, as well as raised, tender, erythematous nodules on the anterior surfaces of his legs.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The chest radiograph reveals a right lower lobe opacity with associated right superior mediastinal widening, suggestive of lymphadenopathy.

The differential diagnosis for nonresolving lobar pneumonia is broad. It includes malignancy, inflammatory diseases, drug reactions, and vascular disease, but infection should always be ruled out first. In regions such as the southwestern United States, certain mycoses are endemic, so suspicion for them should be high. In a patient who lives in that region, has radiographic evidence of a lobar opacity, and has erythema nodosum, the diagnosis of coccidioidomycosis is very likely.

Key learning point: A relatively common cause of nonresolving pneumonia in the southwestern United States is coccidioidomycosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is a reaction to an organic environmental antigen and is characterized by bilateral pulmonary opacities. Nocardiosis, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and cryptogenic organizing pneumonia are not associated with erythema nodosum and are less likely diagnoses than coccidioidomycosis in settings where coccidioides are endemic.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia, a noninfectious inflammatory pneumonia, often occurs as a result of prior infection or drug exposure. Nocardiosis, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and cryptogenic organizing pneumonia are not associated with erythema nodosum and are less likely diagnoses than coccidioidomycosis in settings where coccidioides are endemic.

D) INCORRECT:

Drug-resistant bacterial pneumonia is unlikely in a patient who has not had a precipitating health care exposure.

E) INCORRECT:

Nocardiosis, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and cryptogenic organizing pneumonia are not associated with erythema nodosum and are less likely diagnoses than coccidioidomycosis in settings where coccidioides are endemic.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man from Indiana presents to the emergency department with intermittent left-sided chest pain that has worsened during the past 4 weeks. He has had no associated dyspnea, fever, or myalgias. He does report having a mild cold a few months ago, but his symptoms resolved within a week. He has no medical problems, takes no medications, and does not drink alcohol. He smokes occasional cigars but has never smoked cigarettes.
His heart rate is 86 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 132/74 mm Hg, and his respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute; he is afebrile. His lungs are clear to auscultation, and no murmurs or rubs are audible. The rest of his examination is unremarkable.
Cardiac enzyme levels are normal, and an electrocardiogram shows no abnormality.
A chest radiograph reveals a left upper lobe rounded opacity without any additional abnormalities.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Blastomycosis is caused by inhalation of Blastomyces dermatitidis, a fungus that lives in the soil in North America along the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys, in southeastern states, and in areas around the Great Lakes, including Indiana. The clinical manifestations of blastomycosis range from asymptomatic infection or mild upper respiratory symptoms to respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome; infection can also cause chronic pneumonia as well as pulmonary nodules or masses. Severe disease can occur in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised individuals. Blastomycosis can be treated with a long course of azoles, such as itraconazole.

Key learning point: An immunocompetent patient from the Ohio River basin area who has an acute respiratory illness and a subsequent rounded opacity in the left upper lobe is most likely infected with Blastomyces.

B) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection is most likely to occur in patients with high-risk exposures (incarceration, homelessness, travel to endemic areas or contact with others from endemic areas) or in those who are immunocompromised.

C) INCORRECT:

An acute respiratory illness that is followed by the appearance of a pulmonary nodule is not consistent with a diagnosis of aspergillosis. Although hypersensitivity reactions to inhalation of the fungal spores can cause allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis in healthy patients, Aspergillus infections in the lung are generally limited to immunocompromised patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare infection is associated with structural lung diseases such as bronchiectasis and occurs in immunocompromised hosts.

E) INCORRECT:

Coccidioidomycosis is a fungal disease endemic in certain parts of Arizona, California, Nevada, New Mexico, Texas, Utah, and northern Mexico. It is not prevalent in Indiana. The infection is caused by inhalation of particles. After the acute pulmonary infection resolves, a benign granuloma or scar may be visible on chest radiography.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes presents with acute hemoptysis. She reports that she has a 2-month history of fatigue and a persistent dry cough with occasional episodes of sharp, right-sided pleuritic chest pain. She has had no fevers, sweats, or weight loss. She had a negative tuberculin skin test 3 months ago. She is originally from Mexico and has lived in Florida for many years. Her only recent travel was to Arizona several months ago to visit family.
She is afebrile and has a mild tachycardia. Her pulmonary and cardiac examinations are unremarkable.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10.0
12.0–16.0


Hematocrit (%)
28.0
36.0–46.0


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
12,000
4500–11,000


Neutrophils (%)
60
40–70


Lymphocytes (%)
25
22–44



Eosinophils (%)
15
0–8


A CT scan of the chest is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following tests will help confirm the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Blastomycosis, diagnosed by urine Blastomyces antigen testing, generally occurs in states bordering the Ohio and Mississippi River basins.

Other endemic fungal infections have similar clinical presentations but are not generally associated with peripheral eosinophilia or the distinctive peripheral thin-walled cavitations seen with coccidioidomycosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Paracoccidioidomycosis is limited to Central and South America.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans, diagnosed by Cryptococcus antigen testing, is more frequently associated with nodular lung disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Histoplasmosis, diagnosed by urine and serum Histoplasma antigen testing, generally occurs in states bordering the Ohio and Mississippi River basins.

Other endemic fungal infections have similar clinical presentations but are not generally associated with peripheral eosinophilia or the distinctive peripheral thin-walled cavitations seen with coccidioidomycosis.

E) CORRECT:

Coccidioidomycosis infections have increased dramatically in recent years. This soil-dwelling fungus, endemic to the arid regions of Mexico, Central and South America, and the southwestern United States, is caused by inhalation of arthroconidia. Acute infection can be asymptomatic or consist of a self-limited influenza-like illness; however, symptoms can be subacute and last for months. Approximately 5% to 10% of infections have residual pulmonary sequelae, including nodules or cavities that can lead to hemoptysis. Anti-Coccidioides antibody testing is helpful in establishing the diagnosis, although a negative test does not definitively exclude the diagnosis, particularly if performed early in the course of the disease. If testing is unrevealing, then bronchoscopy is indicated.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a cavitary lung process with hemoptysis and peripheral eosinophilia in a person with travel history to the southwestern United States is coccidioidomycosis.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old woman was admitted to the intensive care unit with respiratory failure, hypoxemia, and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates 2 days ago, after she presented with a 3-week history of progressive dyspnea, intermittent fevers, and dry cough. The initial symptoms began after the patient visited her sister in the Mississippi River valley; treatment with levofloxacin for one week did not improve her symptoms.
On examination today, she is intermittently febrile and hemodynamically stable but remains hypoxemic and requires assist-control ventilation with a positive end-expiratory pressure of 10 cm of water and a fraction of inspired oxygen of 100%. She has bilateral dry crackles.
She was started on vancomycin plus meropenem on admission but has not improved. Preliminary growth from a bronchoscopy specimen suggests a diagnosis of a fungal infection.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with mild-to-moderate histoplasmosis can be treated with oral itraconazole. However, for severe cases, the initial treatment of choice is amphotericin B.

B) INCORRECT:

Posaconazole is effective in vitro, but it is not first-line therapy for histoplasmosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Micafungin has little activity against histoplasmosis.

D) CORRECT:

The development of a fungal pulmonary infection in a patient who was recently residing in the Mississippi River valley is most consistent with a diagnosis of histoplasmosis. An alternative, albeit less common, diagnosis is blastomycosis, which manifests and is treated similarly to histoplasmosis.

Patients with respiratory failure due to histoplasmosis are classified as having severe disease. The antifungal treatment of choice for severe pulmonary histoplasmosis is amphotericin B; a lipid formulation is generally preferred because it has less nephrotoxicity than amphotericin B deoxycholate. Once stable, the patient can make the transition to treatment with oral itraconazole.

Key learning point: The treatment of choice for severe pulmonary histoplasmosis is amphotericin B followed by oral itraconazole.

E) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is less effective than amphotericin B and itraconazole; it is also associated with more relapses.

questions.text:
An 89-year-old woman undergoes emergency exploratory laparotomy for diverticulitis that is complicated by perforation. She is subsequently admitted to the intensive care unit, where her course is complicated by hyperglycemia from known type 2 diabetes, postoperative ileus requiring parenteral nutrition, respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation, and ventilator-associated pneumonia. She is also treated with fluconazole for 7 days because yeast was found in her urine culture; yeast was also found in several tracheal aspirates and in a stool specimen.
On postoperative day 15, despite receiving ceftriaxone and metronidazole, the patient develops fever and severe hypotension that is unresponsive to intravenous fluids. On examination, she is clammy, her central-line insertion site is clean, and her abdomen is soft with a well-healing incision. Testing for Clostridioides difficile infection is negative. The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
In addition to empiric treatment with vancomycin and meropenem, which one of the following agents is most appropriate for this patient to receive while awaiting results of blood cultures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole does not add anaerobic activity to meropenem.

B) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin may provide additional gram-negative coverage for Pseudomonas (depending on local susceptibility patterns) but does not cover Candida, the most likely pathogen.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is a reasonable option for treatment of candidemia in patients who are not critically ill and have not received the drug recently; susceptibility testing is warranted to confirm that the Candida isolate is sensitive to the drug.

D) INCORRECT:

Amphotericin B deoxycholate is not recommended as first-line therapy for suspected candidemia because of its potential nephrotoxicity and the availability of safer, efficacious agents.

E) CORRECT:

Candidemia should be suspected in a patient who develops sepsis or septic shock after abdominal surgery or who has other pertinent risk factors (colonization at other sites, prior use of broad-spectrum antibiotics, previous abdominal surgery, hemodialysis, central venous catheters, or parenteral nutrition). Management in this case should consist of intensification of antibiotic therapy and provision of supportive care for septic shock. Although antifungals might be deferred while the results of blood cultures are pending, this patient is extremely sick and has multiple risk factors for candidemia. In that setting, empiric therapy for candidemia is reasonable. An echinocandin (anidulafungin, caspofungin, or micafungin) is most appropriate for patients with severe illness and for patients with prior use of fluconazole, which increases the risk for azole-resistant Candida infections, such as Candida glabrata.

Key learning point: The type of antifungal agent that is most appropriate to include in a regimen for treating severe candidemia is an echinocandin (anidulafungin, caspofungin, or micafungin).

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents for evaluation of the skin on his right middle finger. He initially noted a “small, round, itchy red spot,” which then gradually spread outward. Examination reveals a 3-cm, well-circumscribed, scaly erythematous patch (figure 1 and figure 2).
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Granuloma annular is an inflammatory plaque that can be similar in shape to tinea corporis (round/annular) but lacks the characteristic scale of tinea because it is a dermal (deeper) rather than epidermal (superficial) process. Low-potency topical glucocorticoids (e.g., hydrocortisone) are often ineffective in managing granuloma annulare.

B) INCORRECT:

Antibacterial agents such as mupirocin are ineffective against dermatophyte infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Granuloma annular is an inflammatory plaque that can be similar in shape to tinea corporis (round/annular) but lacks the characteristic scale of tinea because it is a dermal (deeper) rather than epidermal (superficial) process. Although usually self-limited, persistent, or symptomatic lesions may be treated with a high-potency topical glucocorticoid (e.g., clobetasol).

D) CORRECT:

Tinea corporis, or “ringworm,” is a cutaneous dermatophyte infection usually associated with Trichophyton tonsurans or Trichophyton rubrum, which can be found in soil, on humans, and on animals. Isolated lesions need not raise concern about immunocompetence and are common among children in homes with infected animals and among children who play sports involving significant skin-to-skin contact (e.g., wrestling). Lesions are classically erythematous and annular in nature, with central clearing and a layer of scale at the edges.

Diagnosis of tinea corporis should be confirmed by visualizing hyphae using a potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation or with growth of dermatophyte species on fungal culture.

First-line therapy for isolated tinea corporis lesions on non-hair-bearing sites is a topical antifungal agent. Either an azole antifungal, such as topical clotrimazole, or an allylamine antifungal, such as terbinafine, should be applied twice daily for at least one month and continued until the lesion resolves.

Oral azole and allylamine antifungals are effective against tinea corporis but are rarely indicated for first-line use unless the condition is very widespread or involves hair-bearing sites such as the scalp or eyebrow.

Key learning point: The appropriate first-line therapy for tinea corporis is a topical azole or allylamine antifungal twice daily.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical nystatin is effective against candida species but ineffective against dermatophyte infections.

questions.text:
A healthy 7-year-old girl presents with a scaling, red, annular patch on the right forehead that extends into the eyebrow. Her parents report that her 4-year-old brother has had scaling and alopecia on his scalp for the past 2 months and has not been treated.
A potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation of a scraping of the patient’s skin reveals hyphal forms.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydrocortisone and other topical glucocorticoids, including betamethasone dipropionate, are antiinflammatory medications and will not treat fungal infections. Although topical glucocorticoids may diminish the erythema and pruritus of the rash, the infection often spreads with this use — potentially down hair follicles.

B) CORRECT:

Annular scaling patches are the hallmark of dermatophyte fungal infections, including tinea faciei (also called “ringworm of the face”). In children, the source of dermatophyte infections is often other children, fomites, soil, and animals; therefore, potentially affected siblings and pets should also be evaluated and treated.

Systemic antifungal therapy is indicated for any dermatophyte infection that involves the hair follicles (including tinea capitis, tinea faciei, and tinea corporis on hair-bearing areas of the body), because the fungi proliferate inside the follicles, where topical medications do not penetrate adequately. Several oral agents can be used for treatment, including griseofulvin, fluconazole, itraconazole, and terbinafine. Before treatment is prescribed, the infection should be confirmed with a potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation, dermatophyte fungal culture, or both, because the differential diagnosis of annular lesions on the face includes various forms of lupus, among other diagnoses.

Terbinafine has become a more common treatment choice than griseofulvin, given its shorter course and better efficacy, but longer-term therapy (anticipated treatment >6 weeks) with terbinafine requires monitoring of laboratory results, whereas griseofulvin does not in healthy patients. The expected time course of treatment for tinea faciei is 2 to 4 weeks with oral therapy (which is shorter than would be required for tinea capitis), but the treatment endpoint must be established with clinical evaluation and possible repeat KOH and cultures to confirm cure.

Key learning point: Optimal treatment for tinea faciei that involves the hair follicles requires systemic antifungal therapy, excluding nystatin (which does not treat dermatophyte infections).

C) INCORRECT:

Topical clotrimazole would likely be adequate for the non-hair-bearing areas but may not be fully effective to cure this case given its lack of penetration into the hair follicles.

D) INCORRECT:

Hydrocortisone and other topical glucocorticoids, including betamethasone dipropionate, are antiinflammatory medications and will not treat fungal infections. Although topical glucocorticoids may diminish the erythema and pruritus of the rash, the infection often spreads with this use — potentially down hair follicles. Although topical glucocorticoids are often used for treatment of noninfectious inflammatory dermatoses on the face, this highly potent agent would not be appropriate for use around the eye.

Topical clotrimazole would likely be adequate for the non-hair-bearing areas but may not be fully effective to cure this case given its lack of penetration into the hair follicles.

E) INCORRECT:

Nystatin is an anti-yeast medication and does not treat dermatophytes. In addition, the oral form of this medication is not absorbed through the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 48 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I've got this lumpy rash on my arm.”
History of Present Illness:


2-week history of a nonpruritic rash on his left forearm 

began as a pustule close to the wrist; now spreading to the elbow with nodules and ulcers


Past Medical History:
unremarkable
Medications:
none
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known allergies
Family History:
mother and father: alive with no chronic conditions
Psychosocial History:

does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use other substances
gardener
cat owner

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


36.4°C(97.5°F)
72/min
22/min
125/70 mm Hg
-
183 cm(6 ft)
100 kg(220 lb)
30 kg/m2




Appearance: alert; comfortable
Skin: a photograph is shown

Neck: no lymph nodes palpable
Pulmonary: clear lung fields
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Abdominal: nondistended; nontender to palpation
Extremities: left axillary lymphadenopathy



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Superficial thrombophlebitis usually manifests with tenderness, erythema, and induration that spreads along a superficial vein, often with a palpable cord. Superficial thrombophlebitis rarely ulcerates and most commonly affects superficial veins of the leg in patients with varicose veins or risk factors for venous thromboembolism.

B) CORRECT:

Sporotrichosis is associated with traumatic injury to the skin (e.g., a thorn prick) and most commonly occurs in gardeners and landscapers. This condition manifests at the site of traumatic injury with a papule that usually ulcerates or becomes nodular with overlying erythema; it commonly spreads proximally along lymphatic vessels (i.e., ascending lymphangitis). Systemic symptoms only occur in disseminated infections (e.g., in immunocompromised individuals). Oral itraconazole or potassium iodide is the first-line treatment for cutaneous sporotrichosis. Disseminated infections are treated with IV amphotericin B.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary inoculation tuberculosis is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis transmitted via broken skin or mucosa that manifests with a firm, nontender ulcer and lymphadenopathy. However, this condition typically leads to abscess formation and is associated with inadequately sterilized needles (e.g., from a tattoo) or surgical equipment. Additionally, this condition occurs primarily in children in endemic areas.

D) INCORRECT:

Tularemia can be transmitted by arthropod bites (e.g., ticks, deer flies) or by contact with infected animals; therefore, gardeners and those with pets are at risk. Ulceroglandular tularemia manifests with an ulcer and regional lymphadenopathy, as seen here. However, systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, chills, confusion) and a single ulcer at the entry site of the pathogen, rather than numerous nodular lesions along the lymphatic vessels, would be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Cat scratch disease may manifest with a lesion at the initial site of infection and local lymphadenopathy. Additionally, as a cat owner, this patient is at risk. However, the lesion is usually a papule or pustule and rarely ulcerates or forms nodules. Flu-like symptoms (e.g., headache, fever, myalgia) would also be expected.
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.
questions.hint: A biopsy of the lesion would show cigar-shaped buds.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a 4-week history of intermittent fevers, productive cough, and shortness of breath. Three weeks ago he was treated with amoxicillin-clavulanate and azithromycin, which did not improve his symptoms. He has also noticed “some new bumps on his skin”. He lives in upstate New York along the Mohawk River. He has rheumatoid arthritis. His medications include methotrexate and a multivitamin. His temperature is 38.1ºC (100.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/75 mm Hg. Diffuse crackles are heard over both lung fields. Skin examination shows multiple, white, verrucous papules and nodules on the thighs. A CT scan of the chest shows bilateral tree-in-bud opacities in the lower lobes. A biopsy of a skin nodule shows pyogranulomatous inflammation and round yeast cells. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP pneumonia) is an opportunistic pulmonary infection that manifests with fever, cough, and dyspnea resistant to standard antibiotic treatment, all of which are seen here. However, PCP pneumonia rarely causes cutaneous manifestations. Moreover, PCP pneumonia is almost exclusively seen in immunocompromised patients (e.g., patients with AIDS). A biopsy would show disc-shaped yeast cells rather than round yeast cells.

B) CORRECT:

Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus endemic to the eastern and central United States that causes blastomycosis. This infection most often affects patients who are immunosuppressed or immunocompromised but, unlike most other dimorphic fungal infections, it can cause disseminated disease even in immunocompetent individuals. Blastomycosis typically manifests as pneumonia with extrapulmonary symptoms, which can involve the skin (e.g., verrucous skin lesions and granulomatous nodules, as seen in this patient), genitourinary system (e.g., prostatitis), central nervous system (e.g., meningitis and brain abscesses), and skeletal system (e.g., osteolytic lesions).

Patients who have pulmonary or extrapulmonary blastomycosis that does not affect the central nervous system can be treated with oral azoles (e.g., itraconazole). Severe infection, including cases in which the central nervous system is involved, should be treated with amphotericin B.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2017)

C) INCORRECT:

Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus endemic to the eastern and central United States that causes (disseminated) histoplasmosis, which can manifest as pneumonia with extrapulmonary symptoms (including nodular skin lesions). However, this condition primarily affects patients who are immunocompromised (e.g., patients with AIDS or transplant recipients). A biopsy would show small yeast cells contained within macrophages.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2015)

D) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus fumigatus is a fungus that causes pulmonary aspergillosis, a condition that can manifest with fever, cough, and dyspnea, all of which are seen here. However, cutaneous manifestations of aspergillosis are uncommon. Moreover, a biopsy would show a mold, not yeast cells.

E) INCORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis is a dimorphic fungus that causes disseminated coccidioidomycosis, a condition that can manifest as pneumonia with extrapulmonary symptoms (including nodular skin lesions), which this patient has. However, disseminated coccidioidomycosis primarily affects patients who are immunocompromised (e.g., patients with AIDS). Moreover, Coccidioides immitis is endemic to the southwestern United States, not the eastern and central United States.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2017)
questions.hint: This patient has subacute pneumonia that has not improved with antibiotic therapy. His extrapulmonary manifestations (cutaneous lesions), imaging findings (tree-in-bud opacities in the lower lobes), and biopsy findings (round yeast cells) are characteristic of a disseminated infection caused by a fungus endemic to the eastern and central United States. This patient's infection has disseminated even though he is not significantly immunocompromised (at normal doses, methotrexate has immunomodulatory effects but does not result in severe immunosuppression).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the office because of a dry cough and chest discomfort for the past 3 days. During this period, the patient has had headaches, muscle aches, joint pain, fever, and chills. Ten days ago, she was hiking with her family in Mississippi. The patient has asthma that is treated with an albuterol inhaler. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Physical examination shows slight wheezes throughout both lung fields. Urinalysis is positive for a polysaccharide antigen. Microscopic examination of a bronchoalveolar lavage specimen shows macrophages filled with oval cells that measure 1–5 μm and bud from a narrow base. Culture of the specimen on Sabouraud agar at 24°C grows molds composed of septate hyphae. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungus that is acquired via inhalation and appears as a yeast that buds from a narrow base. It can cause respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough, dyspnea) in immunocompromised patients and, in the case of hematogenous dissemination, results in excretion of a polysaccharide antigen (capsular antigen) in serum and urine. However, C. neoformans is a monomorphic fungus; it would not form hyphae. Also, C. neoformans, which measures 5–10 μm in size, is larger than the cells seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

B) INCORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis is a dimorphic fungus that is acquired via inhalation and coccidioidomycosis can manifest with symptoms of acute pneumonia (valley fever) and joint pain (desert rheumatism), both of which are seen here. However, bronchoalveolar lavage in pulmonary coccidioidomycosis would show large spherules (10–80 μm in size) with multiple endospores. Moreover, the disease is most commonly seen in the Southwestern US, not the Mississippi basin.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Coccidioides immitis in lung tissue (methenamine silver stain; high magnification)

Spherule (red circles) and endospore (green overlays) forms of Coccidioides immitis, a causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, can be seen.

C) INCORRECT:

Infection with the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus (aspergillosis) can manifest with cough, fever, and malaise, and tissue samples would show septate hyphae (with a characteristic 45° branching). Urine might also be positive for a polysaccharide antigen (e.g., galactomannan, beta-D-glucan) in the case of invasive aspergillosis. However, A. fumigatus is a monomorphic fungus; it does not have a yeast form, as seen here. Moreover, since aspergillosis is typically caused by chronic exposure to the fungus, symptoms usually have a gradual progression; acute invasive aspergillosis is less common and only occurs in immunocompromised patients.

D) CORRECT:

Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus endemic to the Mississippi and Ohio river valleys. Infection typically occurs via exposure to bird or bat droppings. Immunocompetent patients with this condition are usually asymptomatic but if a large inoculum of the pathogen is inhaled or the patient is immunocompromised (e.g., the patient has AIDS, transplanted organs, and/or takes immunosuppressive medications), atypical pneumonia (e.g., dry cough, dyspnea) and systemic symptoms (e.g., low-grade fever, malaise, joint pain) can occur. The best initial test in the case of suspected histoplasmosis, especially for patients who are acutely ill, is a urine or serum test for the galactomannan antigen of H. capsulatum. This test is less specific because of crossreaction with antigens of other fungi. A fungal culture of bronchoalveolar lavage is more specific but takes longer (up to 6 weeks). Localized pulmonary histoplasmosis is typically treated with itraconazole and disseminated histoplasmosis with amphotericin B.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2015)

E) INCORRECT:

Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus endemic to the Eastern and Central US (including the Mississippi basin). This pathogen is acquired via inhalation, and blastomycosis manifests as acute pneumonia with systemic symptoms, which is seen here. Urine might also be positive for a polysaccharide antigen in blastomycosis. However, the yeast forms of B. dermatitidis are as large as an erythrocyte (8–10 μm in size) and bud from a broad base; the bronchoalveolar lavage finding of small yeast cells that bud from a narrow base indicates a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (GMS stain)

Thick-walled fungi with single broad-based buds are visible.

This is the typical appearance of Blastomyces dermatitidis in yeast form (at body temperature, 37°C). At room temperature (∼ 23°C ), this dimorphic fungus exists in mold form.
questions.hint: Microbiological examination of the bronchoalveolar lavage shows a dimorphic fungus, which typically exists in a yeast form in body tissue (37°C) and in a hyphal form at room temperature (20–30°C). Microscopic findings also show that the yeast form of this pathogen is intracellular and smaller than an erythrocyte, which is 8–10 μm in size.

questions.text: A 35-year-old military nurse with Crohn disease comes to the office because of a 3-week history of fever, fatigue, dry cough, headache, and myalgia. During this period, he has also had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss. One week ago, he developed several painful oral lesions and difficulty swallowing. He serves at a military base in Ohio. Current medications include prednisone and infliximab. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), respirations are 20/min, pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 115/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diffuse bilateral crackles, hepatosplenomegaly, and multiple 1–2 cm ulcerative lesions with raised borders in the oral mucosa. Laboratory studies show pancytopenia and increased transaminase levels. Results of a combined HIV antigen/antibody testing and an interferon-γ release assay are negative. An x-ray of the chest shows hilar lymphadenopathy with central calcification and multiple well-defined pulmonary nodules measuring 1–10 mm. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Amphotericin B is the best initial pharmacotherapy for disseminated histoplasmosis. Treatment with amphotericin B is given for 1–2 weeks and then followed by treatment with itraconazole for at least 12 months. For patients who are immunosuppressed and have only mild to moderate symptoms, treatment with itraconazole alone is appropriate. Patients who are immunocompetent typically only develop mild pulmonary disease and can be treated supportively.

Pulmonary findings of histoplasmosis and sarcoidosis can be very similar (e.g., pulmonary nodules, hilar lymphadenopathy). Histoplasmosis should be ruled out in endemic regions before starting corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive drugs if sarcoidosis is suspected.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2015)

B) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is used to treat Legionnaires' disease, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles). However, this condition typically manifests with diffuse interstitial infiltrates, not hilar lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules. In addition, Legionnaires' disease does not cause oral ulcers or hepatosplenomegaly. Levofloxacin is not used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is used to treat Pneumocystis pneumonia, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles). However, this condition typically manifests with diffuse interstitial infiltrates, not hilar lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules. In addition, Pneumocystis pneumonia does not cause oral ulcers or hepatosplenomegaly. TMP-SMX is not used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Caspofungin is used to treat invasive candidiasis, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and liver involvement (e.g., increased serum transaminases). However, this condition does not cause oral ulcers and only rarely affects the lungs. Caspofungin is not used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Voriconazole is a first-line treatment for invasive aspergillosis, which can manifest with nonspecific systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles, pulmonary nodules). However, this condition does not cause oral ulcers or hepatosplenomegaly and only rarely causes hilar lymphadenopathy. Voriconazole is not typically used as the initial treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis.
questions.hint: This patient takes immunosuppressive medications and has nonspecific constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss), oral ulcers, hepatosplenomegaly, pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles, hilar lymphadenopathy, well-defined pulmonary nodules), pancytopenia, and increased transaminase levels. These findings, in combination with living in an area endemic for Histoplasma capsulatum (Ohio), are consistent with a diagnosis of disseminated histoplasmosis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-day history of fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, cough, and chest pain. Physical examination shows diffuse inspiratory crackles over the left lung field. An x-ray of the chest shows hilar lymphadenopathy and well-defined nodules with central calcifications. Urine studies show the presence of a polysaccharide antigen. A biopsy specimen of the lung shows cells with basophilic, crescent-shaped nuclei and pericellular halos located within macrophages. This patient's history is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treatment with inhaled glucocorticoids is an important risk factor for developing thrush (oropharyngeal infection with Candida albicans). This condition is not associated with pneumonia, lymphadenopathy, or the biopsy and antigen findings seen in this case. In addition, the characteristic lesions of thrush are white, oropharyngeal patches that show budding yeast and pseudohyphae on KOH preparation, not intracellular organisms.
Image Description:

Typical rod-like, budding structure of Candida albicans (red overlay).

B) INCORRECT:

A recent visit to the Arizona desert is a risk factor for infection with Coccidioides immitis, a dimorphic fungus endemic to the deserts of the southwestern United States, Mexico, and Central and South America. Pulmonary coccidioidomycosis (valley fever) can cause symptoms of acute pneumonia and manifest with lymphadenopathy on chest x-ray, which is seen here. However, it does not explain the antigen findings seen in this case. Additional manifestations of coccidioidomycosis would include arthralgia (“desert rheumatism”) and erythema nodosum or multiforme (“desert bumps”), which this patient does not have. Finally, microscopic evaluation of a biopsy would show spherules containing endospores, not intracellular organisms.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Coccidioides immitis in lung tissue (methenamine silver stain; high magnification)

Spherule (red circles) and endospore (green overlays) forms of Coccidioides immitis, a causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, can be seen.

C) INCORRECT:

A recent trip to Brazil is a risk factor for infection with Paracoccidioides spp., a dimorphic fungus endemic to South and Central America. Paracoccidioidomycosis causes pneumonia but not the antigen findings seen in this case. Additional manifestations include mucosal ulcerations and cervical (not hilar) lymphadenopathy. Biopsy would show budding yeast with a captain's wheel appearance, not intracellular organisms.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (methenamine silver stain)

A circular cell with round budding daughter cells can be seen in the center of the image. This appearance (“pilot's wheel”) is characteristic of Paracoccidioides species. Additional Paracoccidioides cells that do not have the classic appearance can be seen in the upper left.

D) INCORRECT:

Previous mycobacterial infection is a risk factor for pulmonary aspergillosis (aspergilloma) due to colonization of pre-existing lung cavities by inhaled Aspergillus spores. Pulmonary aspergillosis can manifest with fever, cough, and respiratory distress but would be unlikely to cause calcified nodules, hilar lymphadenopathy, or the antigen findings seen in this case. In addition, biopsy of affected tissue would show acute-angle septate hyphae on staining, not intracellular organisms.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

There are numerous elongated, septated hyphae (examples indicated by blue overlay) of uniform diameter and with dichotomous branching at approx. 45° angles.

This is the typical appearance of Aspergillus. A culture is required to determine the exact Aspergillus species.

E) CORRECT:

Bat and bird droppings can carry Histoplasma capsulatum, particularly in endemic areas (e.g., the Ohio and Mississippi river valleys). Inhalation of the fungus causes histoplasmosis, a condition that manifests with primary pulmonary disease or disseminated disease, especially in patients who are immunocompromised.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Intracellular (examples indicated by white arrowheads) and extracellular (examples indicated by black arrowheads) forms of ovoid yeast-like organisms are visible.

The presence of these organisms is indicative of histoplasmosis. Diagnosis must be confirmed by culture and PCR array to determine the exact species (Histoplasma capsulatum in this case).
questions.hint: This woman has pneumonia (fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, cough, chest pain, crackles), hilar lymphadenopathy, a polysaccharide antigen in the urine, and a biopsy specimen of the lung that shows yeast cells within macrophages, all of which are features of Histoplasma capsulatum infection.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male missionary reports one month of a nonproductive cough that began 5 days after he returned from a trip to Nicaragua. The cough is associated with fevers, chills, night sweats, myalgias, and mild shortness of breath. The patient reports no exposures to wild animals and no new sexual contacts, but he did stay in a hotel that was being remodeled. The patient's vital signs are normal, and his physical examination is unremarkable. CT of the chest is obtained (figure). A subsequent lung biopsy reveals necrotizing granulomatous pneumonitis with numerous fungal organisms. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aspergillosis is almost always seen in immunocompromised patients. It is generally a more indolent disease than histoplasmosis and has larger nodules, with an associated halo.

B) INCORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis is also endemic to certain areas of Central and South America but is less prevalent than Histoplasma. Chest imaging is more likely to reveal a focal opacity, reticulonodular changes, or thin-walled, apical cavities.

C) INCORRECT:

Blastomycosis is uncommon in Central and South America.

D) CORRECT:

Histoplasma capsulatum is endemic in Central and South America, so acute histoplasmosis should be on the differential diagnosis for travelers with new pulmonary symptoms who return from those regions.

Acute histoplasmosis usually manifests as a flulike illness characterized by high-grade fever, chills, headache, nonproductive cough, and fatigue. Chest imaging often reveals diffuse reticulonodular infiltrates. Symptoms typically occur 1 to 3 weeks after exposure, and most affected patients recover spontaneously within 3 weeks. Treatment is usually unnecessary for mild-to-moderate disease. If symptoms last more than one month, itraconazole (200 mg three times daily for 3 days, then 200 mg once or twice daily for 6 to 12 weeks) is recommended.

Key learning point: The most likely acute pulmonary fungal infection in a traveler returning from Central or South America is histoplasmosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is endemic in northeastern South America and in Central America. Paracoccidioides typically causes an asymptomatic primary pulmonary infection, but an acute disseminated infection may occur. Acute disseminated infections account for fewer than 10% of cases and are rare in adults over age 30.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman is hospitalized with a one-month history of low-grade fevers, chills, weight loss, and cough that produces yellow sputum. She was recently treated with a course of azithromycin as an outpatient but reports no improvement in her symptoms. She has lived in Indiana her whole life and has never traveled outside the United States. She has worked as a middle school teacher since age 25; she has never smoked or had a positive tuberculin skin test. Her chest radiograph reveals a single, round opacity in the right lower lobe. Which one of the following tests is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s one-month history of low-grade fevers, chills, weight loss, and cough productive of yellow sputum is consistent with chronic pneumonia. The most common cause of chronic pneumonia is Mycobacterium tuberculosis, but alternative causes also exist, and the most common of these is infection with an endemic fungus (e.g., blastomycosis, histoplasmosis, or coccidioidomycosis). Diagnosis of fungal infection is best made with antigen testing (for Histoplasma or Blastomyces) or antibody testing. In this case, a single, rounded opacity on chest radiograph in a patient from Indiana is most consistent with histoplasmosis or blastomycosis.

Key learning point: For a patient with no exposure to tuberculosis, the most common cause of chronic pneumonia is fungal infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Influenza infection causes acute pneumonia and would manifest with days, not weeks, of symptoms. Thus, influenza nasal swab testing would not be appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Although open lung biopsy is occasionally required to diagnose a chronic pneumonia, it is invasive and should be deferred unless noninvasive tests are unrevealing. Prior to an open lung biopsy, sputum studies and bronchoscopy should be performed.

D) INCORRECT:

Legionella infection causes acute pneumonia and would manifest with days, not weeks, of symptoms. Thus, Legionella urinary antigen would not be appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

If there is concern for tuberculosis, sputum stain and culture for acid-fast bacilli would be appropriate to diagnose active infection. A tuberculin skin test, which is used to diagnose latent tuberculosis infection, would not be helpful.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man with a history of well-controlled hypertension presents with persistent cough, malaise, and night sweats. He resides permanently in New Mexico and has had the symptoms for 6 weeks despite two courses of antibiotics, first with azithromycin and then with levofloxacin. His only other medication is lisinopril. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F) and an oxygen saturation is 92% while breathing ambient air. Physical examination reveals faint inspiratory crackles in his right lower lung field, as well as raised, tender, erythematous nodules on the anterior surfaces of his legs. A chest radiograph is shown. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The differential diagnosis for nonresolving lobar pneumonia is broad. It includes malignancy, inflammatory diseases, drug reactions, and vascular disease, but infection should always be ruled out first. In regions such as the southwestern United States, certain mycoses are endemic, so suspicion for them should be high. In a patient who lives in that region who has radiographic evidence of a lobar opacity and erythema nodosum, the diagnosis of coccidioidomycosis is very likely.

Key learning point: A relatively common cause of nonresolving pneumonia in the southwestern United States is coccidioidomycosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is a reaction to an organic environmental antigen and is characterized by bilateral pulmonary opacities. Nocardiosis, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and cryptogenic organizing pneumonia are not associated with erythema nodosum and are less likely diagnoses than coccidioidomycosis in settings where coccidioides are endemic.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia, a noninfectious inflammatory pneumonia, often occurs as a result of prior infection or drug exposure. Nocardiosis, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and cryptogenic organizing pneumonia are not associated with erythema nodosum and are less likely diagnoses than coccidioidomycosis in settings where coccidioides are endemic.

D) INCORRECT:

Drug-resistant bacterial pneumonia is unlikely in a patient who has not had a precipitating health care exposure.

E) INCORRECT:

Nocardiosis, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and cryptogenic organizing pneumonia are not associated with erythema nodosum and are less likely diagnoses than coccidioidomycosis in settings where coccidioides are endemic.
questions.hint: The chest radiograph shows a right lower lobe opacity with associated right superior mediastinal widening, suggestive of lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, cough, and chest pain. On examination, there are diffuse inspiratory crackles over the left lung field. Chest x-ray shows hilar lymphadenopathy and well-defined nodules with central calcifications. Urine studies reveal a polysaccharide antigen. Lung biopsy shows cells with basophilic, crescent-shaped nuclei and pericellular halos within macrophages. Which one of the following is most likely to be found in her history?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A recent visit to the Arizona desert is a risk factor for infection with Coccidioides immitis, a dimorphic fungus endemic to the deserts of the southwestern United States, Mexico, and Central and South America. Pulmonary coccidioidomycosis (valley fever) can cause symptoms of acute pneumonia and manifest with lymphadenopathy on chest x-ray, which is seen here. However, it does not explain the antigen findings seen in this case. Additional manifestations of coccidioidomycosis would include arthralgia (“desert rheumatism”) and erythema nodosum or multiforme (“desert bumps”), which this patient does not have. Finally, microscopic evaluation of a biopsy would show spherules containing endospores, not intracellular organisms.

B) INCORRECT:

Treatment with inhaled glucocorticoids is an important risk factor for developing thrush (oropharyngeal infection with Candida albicans). This condition is not associated with pneumonia, lymphadenopathy, or the biopsy and antigen findings seen in this case. In addition, the characteristic lesions of thrush are white, oropharyngeal patches that show budding yeast and pseudohyphae on KOH preparation, not intracellular organisms.

C) INCORRECT:

A recent trip to Brazil is a risk factor for infection with Paracoccidioides spp., a dimorphic fungus endemic to South and Central America. Paracoccidioidomycosis causes pneumonia but not the antigen findings seen in this case. Additional manifestations include mucosal ulcerations and cervical (not hilar) lymphadenopathy. Biopsy would show budding yeast with a captain's wheel appearance, not intracellular organisms.

D) INCORRECT:

Previous mycobacterial infection is a risk factor for pulmonary aspergillosis (aspergilloma) due to colonization of pre-existing lung cavities by inhaled Aspergillus spores. Pulmonary aspergillosis can manifest with fever, cough, and respiratory distress but would be unlikely to cause calcified nodules, hilar lymphadenopathy, or the antigen findings seen in this case. In addition, biopsy of affected tissue would show acute-angle septate hyphae on staining, not intracellular organisms.

E) CORRECT:

Bat and bird droppings can carry Histoplasma capsulatum, particularly in endemic areas (e.g., the Ohio and Mississippi river valleys). Inhalation of the fungus causes histoplasmosis, a condition that manifests with primary pulmonary disease or disseminated disease, especially in patients who are immunocompromised.

Key learning point: Histoplasmosis is commonly acquired by inhaling spores from bat or bird droppings, especially in the Ohio and Mississippi river valleys.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Intracellular (examples indicated by white arrowheads) and extracellular (examples indicated by black arrowheads) forms of ovoid yeast-like organisms are visible.

The presence of these organisms is indicative of histoplasmosis. Diagnosis must be confirmed by culture and PCR array to determine the exact species (Histoplasma capsulatum in this case).
questions.hint: This woman has pneumonia (fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, cough, chest pain, crackles), hilar lymphadenopathy, a polysaccharide antigen in the urine, and a biopsy specimen of the lung that shows yeast cells within macrophages, all of which are features of Histoplasma capsulatum infection.

questions.text: You are caring for a 37-year-old woman who is hospitalized with a one-month history of low-grade fevers, chills, weight loss, and a cough productive of yellow sputum. She recently completed a course of azithromycin as an outpatient without improvement. She has lived in Ontario her entire life and has not traveled outside Canada. She works as a middle school teacher, has never smoked, and has never had a positive tuberculin skin test. Her chest radiograph shows a single, round opacity in the right lower lobe. Which one of the following tests is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s one-month history of low-grade fevers, chills, weight loss, and cough productive of yellow sputum is consistent with chronic pneumonia. The most common cause of chronic pneumonia is tuberculosis, but alternative causes also exist, and the most common of these is infection with an endemic fungus (e.g., blastomycosis, histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis). In Canada, histoplasmosis is endemic in Ontario and Quebec, while blastomycosis is endemic in Ontario, Manitoba, Quebec, and Saskatchewan. Serum and/or urine rapid antigen tests can quickly identify the presence of these fungal infections while awaiting definitive diagnosis with culture and/or histopathology.

Key learning point: For a patient with no exposure to tuberculosis, the most common cause of chronic pneumonia is fungal infection.

B) INCORRECT:

If there is concern for tuberculosis, sputum stain and culture for acid-fast bacilli would be appropriate to diagnose active infection. A tuberculin skin test, which is used to diagnose latent tuberculosis infection, would not be helpful.

C) INCORRECT:

Influenza infection causes acute pneumonia and usually manifests with days, not weeks, of symptoms. Moreover, the radiologic findings seen in this patient are not typical of influenza infection. Thus, a different diagnostic test would be more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Although open lung biopsy is occasionally required to diagnose a chronic pneumonia, it is invasive and should be deferred unless noninvasive tests are unrevealing. Prior to an open lung biopsy, sputum studies and bronchoscopy should be performed.

E) INCORRECT:

Legionella infection causes acute pneumonia and would manifest with days, not weeks, of symptoms. Thus, Legionella urinary antigen would not be appropriate.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a history of rheumatoid arthritis and poorly controlled diabetes presents to the emergency department with fever, nasal congestion, and severe right facial pain for the past 3 days. He takes daily prednisone. An image of his examination is shown. CT shows mucosal thickening of the right maxillary sinus with bony erosions of the maxillary roof and extension into the right orbit. β-D-glucan and galactomannan assays are negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- The clinical findings of a necrotic eschar on the right eyelid and nose and CT findings of sinusitis with bony erosions strongly suggest a diagnosis of mucormycosis. The negative β-D-glucan and galactomannan assays help exclude other opportunistic fungal infections since mucormycosis does not produce these biomarkers.

B) INCORRECT:

Aspergillosis typically causes a pulmonary infection rather than the rhino-orbital-cerebral infection pattern seen in this patient. Additionally, aspergillosis results in positive β-D-glucan and galactomannan assays.

C) INCORRECT:

Candidiasis can cause various focal infections (e.g., endocarditis, endophthalmitis) but rarely causes the rhino-orbital-cerebral infection pattern seen in this patient. Additionally, candidiasis results in a positive β-D-glucan assay.

D) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcosis typically causes meningoencephalitis or a pulmonary infection rather than the rhino-orbital-cerebral infection pattern seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis pneumonia typically causes a pulmonary infection rather than the rhino-orbital-cerebral infection pattern seen in this patient. Additionally, pneumocystis pneumonia results in a positive β-D-glucan assay.

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of a rash on the back. The rash is shown. The rash shows numerous hypopigmented, well-demarcated macules are visible on the patient's back. The lesions show fine scaling and coalesce in some regions. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral terbinafine is not an effective treatment for pityriasis versicolor.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is an antibiotic that can treat skin and soft tissue bacterial infections, but it is not effective against fungal infections such as pityriasis versicolor.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Topical clotrimazole is an azole antifungal that effectively treats pityriasis versicolor. Topical therapy is first-line treatment for localized disease and has fewer adverse effects and lower cost compared to systemic alternatives.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical mupirocin is an antibiotic ointment that can treat skin and soft tissue bacterial infections, but it is not effective against fungal infections such as pityriasis versicolor.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral griseofulvin is not an effective treatment for pityriasis versicolor.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man who is a collegiate wrestler presents with a 1-week history of pruritic lesions on his left arm. An image of his skin lesions is shown. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral griseofulvin is used for systemic therapy when oral treatment is indicated, such as in tinea capitis. This localized tinea corporis can be effectively treated with topical therapy as the initial approach.

B) INCORRECT:

Nystatin is primarily effective against Candida species. Nystatin is not effective against dermatophytes.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral fluconazole is indicated for systemic therapy in patients with extensive spread, immunodeficiency, or refractory disease. This patient's localized infection can be effectively managed with topical therapy as the initial approach.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has tinea corporis based on the characteristic annular lesions with central clearing and scaling borders. Topical antifungal therapy is the appropriate first-line treatment for localized tinea corporis, tinea cruris, and tinea pedis. Terbinafine is an effective topical agent for dermatophyte infections.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroid creams will not treat the underlying dermatophyte infection.

questions.text: A 35-year-old spelunker presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of fever, weight loss, and nonproductive cough after exploring caves in Ohio. Physical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly and ulcerative lesions on the hard palate and tongue. Chest radiograph shows diffuse nodular densities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paracoccidioidomycosis is endemic to South and Central America, not the Ohio region where this patient was spelunking. While paracoccidioidomycosis can cause mucosal ulcerations, this patient's geographic exposure history makes this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

While blastomycosis can cause pneumonia and systemic symptoms, it does not typically cause oral ulcerative lesions.

C) INCORRECT:

Coccidioidomycosis is endemic to the southwestern United States and California, not Ohio, where this patient was exploring caves. While coccidioidomycosis can manifest with pneumonia and systemic symptoms, ulcerative oral lesions are not characteristic features of this infection.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's clinical presentation of fever, weight loss, nonproductive cough, hepatosplenomegaly, and characteristic ulcerative oral lesions on the palate and tongue, combined with diffuse nodular densities on chest radiograph, suggests disseminated histoplasmosis. Histoplasmosis is endemic to the Mississippi and Ohio river valleys, making this diagnosis highly likely based on this patient's spelunking activities in Ohio. Cave exploration is a risk factor because bat droppings can contain Histoplasma capsulatum spores.

E) INCORRECT:

Sporotrichosis typically results from traumatic skin injury during gardening activities, not cave exploration. This infection classically manifests with cutaneous lesions showing ascending lymphangitis along draining lymphatics rather than the systemic symptoms, hepatosplenomegaly, and oral ulcerative lesions described in this patient.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 5-day history of progressive skin lesions to her right hand and arm after pricking her right index finger on a rose thorn while gardening. Her examination is shown. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin does not have antifungal properties and is ineffective for treating sporotrichosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Mupirocin does not have antifungal properties and is ineffective for treating sporotrichosis.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Itraconazole is the first-line oral antifungal treatment for cutaneous and lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. Treatment should continue for 2–4 weeks after complete resolution of all lesions to prevent recurrence.

D) INCORRECT:

Amphotericin B is used to treat disseminated sporotrichosis, not cutaneous or lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

E) INCORRECT:
