Clotrimazole is an ineffective treatment for sporotrichosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the clinic because of a one-week history of fever, nonproductive cough, headache, and muscle aches. He returned 10 days ago from a trip to Kentucky, where he participated in spelunking (cave exploration). He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg. Physical examination is unremarkable, and lung auscultation is clear. A chest x-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and diffuse, small, nodular infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Blastomycosis is an endemic fungal infection with geographic overlap in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys. Although it can cause a flu-like illness, it typically manifests with extrapulmonary findings such as cutaneous and bone lesions. Furthermore, chest x-ray typically shows lobar consolidation, mimicking bacterial pneumonia or a mass-like lesion, rather than the prominent hilar lymphadenopathy and diffuse nodular pattern seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Coccidioidomycosis, or "Valley fever," can manifest with flu-like symptoms and can show bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and diffuse nodular infiltrates on imaging. However, it is geographically unlikely to occur in a patient who traveled to Kentucky, as this fungus is endemic to the arid, southwestern United States, such as Arizona and California's San Joaquin Valley. Another condition is more likely.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is highly suggestive of acute pulmonary histoplasmosis, which is caused by the dimorphic fungus Histoplasma capsulatum. The diagnosis is supported by the patient's flu-like illness (fever, cough, myalgias), relevant exposure history (spelunking, travel), and imaging findings (hilar lymphadenopathy and diffuse, small, nodular infiltrates). This fungus is endemic to the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys, and infection occurs via inhalation of spores from soil contaminated with bird or bat droppings. High-risk activities include spelunking (cave exploration), cleaning chicken coops, or demolition. Most cases in immunocompetent individuals are self-limiting and resolve without specific treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has symptoms consistent with pneumonia, typical bacterial pneumonia usually manifests with a productive cough and focal lobar consolidation on a chest x-ray. Atypical pneumonias can manifest with a nonproductive cough, but the prominent bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and specific spelunking exposure make another condition a much more likely cause.
questions.hint: The causative pathogen for this condition is endemic to the Ohio and Mississippi River areas.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of fever, night sweats, malaise, dyspnea, and a productive cough with bloody sputum for 4 days. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 15 years ago and has not been adherent with his medication regimen. Physical examination shows diminished breath sounds over the left lung fields. An x-ray of the chest shows an ill-defined lesion in the upper lobe of the left lung. A CT-guided biopsy of the lesion is performed; a photomicrograph of the biopsy specimen stained with mucicarmine is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis infections cause coccidioidomycosis, a fungal infection that is often asymptomatic but can manifest with fever, cough, and malaise. However, methenamine silver staining would reveal spherules filled with endospores. Furthermore, C. immitis does not have a polysaccharide capsule, so it does not stain with mucicarmine.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Coccidioides immitis in lung tissue (methenamine silver stain; high magnification)

Spherule (red circles) and endospore (green overlays) forms of Coccidioides immitis, a causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, can be seen.

B) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans is a fungus that may affect the lungs in cases of severe immunosuppression, which manifests with fever, malaise, dyspnea, and cough. KOH staining would show budding yeasts with hyphae and pseudohyphae. However, since C. albicans does not have a polysaccharide capsule, it does not stain with mucicarmine.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of fungus germination (KOH preparation, 600x)

Mother cells (blastospores; green overlay) produce a hyphal outgrowth of germ tubes (budding; dashed red outline).

Budding is suggestive of active candida infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis jirovecii causes pneumocystis pneumonia. P. jirovecii is commonly associated with immunodeficiency (e.g., AIDS), manifests with cough, fever, and malaise, and is visible on silver staining as disc-shaped cysts with central spores. It does not possess a polysaccharide capsule, so it does not stain with mucicarmine.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of alveolar tissue infected with P. jirovecii (Grocott's methenamine silver stain, high magnification)

The cysts of this fungus are located within the alveoli together with an inflammatory exudate (red overlay). The cyst walls are stained black in this silver stain.

D) INCORRECT:

Histoplasma capsulatum is a fungus that can cause histoplasmosis in immunocompromised patients. While histoplasmosis often remains asymptomatic, it can manifest as a flu-like illness, with fever, weight loss, erythema nodosum, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and a nonproductive cough. H. capsulatum stains with either silver, Giemsa, or PAS (showing ovoid yeast), not with the narrow-spectrum mucicarmine used here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Intracellular (examples indicated by white arrowheads) and extracellular (examples indicated by black arrowheads) forms of ovoid yeast-like organisms are visible.

The presence of these organisms is indicative of histoplasmosis. Diagnosis must be confirmed by culture and PCR array to determine the exact species (Histoplasma capsulatum in this case).

E) INCORRECT:

Infection with Blastomyces dermatitidis can cause pneumonia, which is seen in this patient. On staining, B. dermatitidis appears as a multinucleated yeast that forms broad-based buds. However, because it has a thin mucopolysaccharide layer, mucicarmine stains B. dermatitidis light red.

F) CORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans is a pathogenic fungus that has a thick polysaccharide capsule, which causes it to stain bright red with mucicarmine. India ink is another dye commonly used to stain C. neoformans. The ink is considered a negative dye; it does not penetrate the polysaccharide capsule of C. neoformans and it leaves a light halo around the fungus. The fungus is primarily transmitted via soil or pigeon droppings and initially infects the respiratory tract. Infection is typically asymptomatic, but cryptococcosis may occur, especially in immunodeficient individuals (e.g., with AIDS). Cryptococcosis usually manifests as isolated pneumonia, and can also manifest as cryptococcal meningoencephalitis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (mucicarmine stain; high magnification)

A widened alveolar septum with inflammatory cell infiltration (white arrowheads: macrophages; black arrowhead: neutrophil granulocyte) and yeasts of Cryptococcus neoformans (green overlay) are visible.

These findings are typical of pulmonary cryptococcosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus fumigatus infections cause aspergillosis, which can manifest with pneumonia. H&E, silver, or PAS staining of A. fumigatus would show septate hyphae with fruiting bodies branching at 45° angles. A. fumigatus does not possess a mucin capsule, so it does not stain with mucicarmine.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

There are numerous elongated, septated hyphae (examples indicated by blue overlay) of uniform diameter and with dichotomous branching at approx. 45° angles.

This is the typical appearance of Aspergillus. A culture is required to determine the exact Aspergillus species.
questions.hint: This immunocompromised (HIV) patient has pneumonia (fever, night sweats, malaise, dyspnea, a productive cough with bloody sputum, diminished breath sounds, and lesions on x-ray). The photomicrograph shows ovoid yeast and some narrow-necked budding. Mucicarmine is a narrow-spectrum stain used to identify one particular fungal organism with a thick polysaccharide capsule.
